dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm sorry, Joy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's okay.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Is there anything I can get you?  Do you want me to take care of anything for you or...?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, no, no.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: ...pick up anything?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know you are welcome to stay at my house if you want to just check out for a couple days and hang out.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's sweet.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Thank you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I went to see her headstone a week or two ago.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I used to go to cemeteries a lot before she died.  I just, you know, I felt like they were urban oasis, you know, there is always this green in the city.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Hmm.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: So I was like wandering around before.  It takes forever to find her headstone; I always lose it. You know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: So I was looking at this other one and there was like a piece of candy there and I thought that I would take the candy and put it on her headstone.  And-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: this woman came up and, you know, it was hers. It was her person that was there.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh.  She was there?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.  And she was like, that's pathetic, I hope you enjoy it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And I, you know, I mean, I said I was sorry and I brought it back to her kind of and I like put it on the ground and she was like, no, it's fine.  She was like, I would rather have her back, honestly.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Mmhmm.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't know.  It just, like, I felt so bad because I shouldn't have done it.  I don't know.  Whatever.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't know.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How long were you there for?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: At the cemetery?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Mmhmm.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: couple hours.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I brought- I brought Chuck with me. He went to Redlands, yeah, for the day.  We ran through the sprinklers.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh really?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You ran through the sprinklers in the cemetery?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It was hot.[LIPSMACK]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Is it a big cemetery?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.  It's huge.  Redlands is an old city so they have lots and lots of stones.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, so they're like really old too, really old ones?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's weird.  Whenever I go back to town, I think of her.  I mean, it's like ... I mean we grew up together and she died when we were twenty one.  And yeah.  She had cancer, she had two brain tumors.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: My best friend Heather.  She's got a- we have a- we built this like little--  There's a park, Prospect Park.  And there is like a garden section of it that we set up for her.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: She used to have these poetry parties on Memorial Day.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Mmhmm.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Umm. Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And the last time before she died, I remember she couldn't really stand, umm...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: But I mean she could, but it was- so it was kind of sitting at her feet holding her up and she had these poems she had memorized.  And I remember looking up, she had curly red hair and there was this palm tree right behind her and it was like a crown growing right out of her head.  It was cool.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Mmhmm.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Some, I guess.  She memorized this one, John Dunn, it's called, Death Be Not Proud. and-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So she wrote a lot of poetry?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: There's another one, I can't remember.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I remember, too, when we were--  she died at U.C.L.A.  She had brain surgery and there was not much hope to begin with, but I gave blood for her surgery, her mom and I before, so we dropped her off in the waiting room and then we were giving blood and came back.  And she, in her wheelchair, like can hardly do anything, reciting her poetry for these people like in the waiting room.  All she needs is a God damn audience.  You know?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Mmhmm.Mmhmm.Mmhmm.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Excuse me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Do you have your forms?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Let me see them.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Is there a problem?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Who told you to get in this line?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You did.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You were standing at the beginning and you directed me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay. But I didn't tell you to get in this line if you are filling out this particular form.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well what's the problem?  Let me change it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: This form is a Z.X.four.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You can't--  This is not the line for Z.X.four.  If you're going to fill out the Z.X.four, you need to have a different form of ID.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What?  I'm getting an ID.  This is why I'm here.  My wallet was stolen.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No. I need another set of ID to prove this is actually you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How am I supposed to get an ID without an ID?  How does a person get an ID in the first place?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know.  But I need an ID to pass this form along.  I can't just send it along without an ID.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm here to get an ID.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No.  I need another ID, a separate one.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Like what?  Like a birth certificate?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: A birth certificate, a passport...a student ID; didn't you go to school?  Anything?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Who the hell has a birth certificate?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes but my wallet was stolen, I don't have anything.  I don't have any credit cards, I don't have my ID.  Don't you have things on file here?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.  We keep it on file, but we need an ID to access that file.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's out of control.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't understand why this is so complicated for people when they get here.  It's just a simple form.  I just need an ID.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How long have you been working here?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Actually too long.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Clearly.  You know, do you have like a supervisor or something?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.  Do you want to see my supervisor?  Huh? Yeah.  Do you want to see my supervisor?  Fine.  I'll be right back.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That would - I would appreciate that.  Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Good God.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Is it them?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I wonder.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Freda is the only one who knows we are here.  She wouldn't ring up.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It must be them then.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It had to happen sooner or later.  What are we going to do?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We are okay, aren't we darling?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Now and always, sweet.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't care then.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It had to happen sooner or later.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Hello?  Hello?  I'm sorry, what's that?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No.  Wrong number. [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER] That sent shivers up my spine.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What shall we do if they suddenly walk in on us.[LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: We'll behave exquisitely.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: With perfect poise.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I think I shall do a curtsy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's strange; things that ought to matter dreadfully, they just don't matter at all when one's happy.  Do they?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Hmm.  The pity is that one can't stay happy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Darling, don't say that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's true.  I think the whole thing's a cruel joke.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What?  This beautiful and sacred thing - love?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes.  Meaning just that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well what does it all mean?  That's what I ask myself in my quest for ultimate truth.  Dear God, what does it all mean?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Don't laugh at me.  I'm being serious.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh darling, you mustn't be serious.  It's just what they want.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Who's they?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All of those futile moralists who make life unbearable.  You have to laugh at them, be flippant.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know, flippancy brings out the acid in their darned, light and sweetness.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: you know if I laugh at everything then I must laugh at us, too.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh of course.  We are figures of fun.  All right.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How long with it last, this ludicrous overbearing love of ours?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Who knows?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Shall we always want to bicker and fight?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh no.  That fire will fade along with our passion.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh dear, should we like that?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well it depends on how well we've played.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What happens if one of us dies?  Does the other one still laugh?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes.  Yes with all of his might.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well that's serious enough, isn't it?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, no, no, no. no.  Death is a very laughable thing.  It's a cunning little mystery, it's all done with mirrors.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I think you are talking nonsense.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh.  So is everyone, in the long run.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Let's be superficial, and just pity those poor philosophers, huh?  Let's blow trumpets and squeakers and enjoy the party for as long as we can, you know, like small, idiotic school children.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh Come and kiss me darling before your body rots and worms pop out of your eye sockets.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh Elliott, worms don't pop.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh See, I don't care what you do, see.  You can paint yourself green and run naked through the Place Vendome and run off with all of the men of the world.  I shan't say a word, just as long as you love me best.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Aw.  Thank you, darling.  The same applies to you too, except that if you so much as look at another woman I'll kill you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Do you remember that awful scene we had in Venice?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Which particular one?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: The one where you put that tiny painted wooden snake in my bed.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh Charles, that was his name.  He did wiggle so beautifully.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [GARBAGE]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It was a terrible thing.  I hated it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know you did.  You threw him out the window into the Grand Canal.  I'll never forgive you for that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How long did that row last?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It went on intermittently for days.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Uh huh.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: But the worst one was in Cannes when your curling irons burnt a hole in my new dressing gown.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh And it burnt my comb, too, and all of those towels in the bathroom.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That was a rouser, wasn't it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER] That was the first time you hit me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I did not hit you very hard.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: The manager came in, he found us rolling about the floor, biting and scratching like panthers. [LAUGHTER]  How utterly, utterly ridiculous.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER] I'll never forget his face. [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER] We were very much younger then.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER] And very much sillier.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: However I believe the real cause of that row was Peter Burden.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh.  You knew there was nothing in that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We were very much younger then.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And very much sillier.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: However I believe the real cause of that row was Peter Burden.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh.  You knew there was nothing in that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I knew nothing of the sort.  You took presents from him.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Presents?  It was only a trivial, little brooch.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It was bristling with diamonds.  In the worst possible taste, too.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It was not.  I still have it, and I wear it often.  It is very pretty.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You went out of your way to torture me over Peter Burden.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I did not.  You worked that whole thing up in your jealous imagination.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, you let him kiss you, huh?  You said you did.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, what of it?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What of it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It gave him a lot of pleasure and it didn't hurt me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What about me?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: If you hadn't been so suspicious and nosey, you never would have known a thing about it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That's a nice point of view, I must say.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh dear.  I'm bored with this conversation.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So am I.  I'm bored stiff. [GARBAGE]  Do you want some brandy?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.  Thank you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'll have a little, I think.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't know why you'd want any, you've already had three glasses.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No particular reason.  Anyhow, they are very small ones.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I just think it's silly to go on and on and on about such a thing.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You can hardly call three glasses of liquor a whole evening long, going on and on and on.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's become a habit with you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh.  Don't be so grand.  Just because you don't happen to want one at the moment.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Don't be stupid.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Really, Amanda.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Nothing.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: you going out somewhere, dear?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.  I am just making myself fascinating for you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That reply has broken my heart.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh.  It's a woman's duty to allure the man.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well as a matter of fact, yes, that's perfectly true.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No it isn't.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes it is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You shut up.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh really.  It's a pity you didn't have any brandy, it would have made you a little less disagreeable.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's funny it hasn't worked such wonders for you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Snap, snap, snap.  You know you are like a little adder.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Adders don't snap, they sting.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Nonsense.  They have a bag of venom behind their fangs and they snap. They snap.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: They sting. I don't care.  Do you understand?  I don't care if they bark and they roll about like hoops.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Did you see much of Peter Burden after our divorce?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes I did, quite a lot.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And I suppose you let him kiss you a good deal more than, too. Yes.  I suppose you guys had a riotous time, huh?  All out, no restraint at all.  Well, you never really had much anyhow.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Mind your own business.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're quite insufferable, I expect it's because you are drunk.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I think I am not in the least bit drunk.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You've always had a weak head.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I think I mentioned once before that I've had three minute liquor glasses the whole evening long.  A child of two cannot get drunk on that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: On the contrary, a child of two can get violently drunk on only one glass of brandy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That's very interesting Amanda. How about a child of four?  Or a child of six?  Or a child of nine? We can get a good little conversation going on about this, you know, intemperate tots.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh shut up.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Shut up.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Not very funny, darling.  Why don't you have some more brandy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER] That's a very good idea.  I think I will.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Look, you better turn that off. I don't want to wake up the people upstairs.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Why?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: There are no people upstairs; it's a photographer's studio.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well then you'll wake up the people downstairs.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: They are away in Tunis.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: This is no time of year for Tunis.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Turn it on again, please.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I will do no such thing.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Fine if you insist on being boorish and idiotic.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Will you turn that off, it's driving me mad.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You are far too temperamental, try to control yourself.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Turn it off.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I won't.  Let go, let go of me. Listen, listen?  I'm sick and tired of listening to you, you sadistic bully.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Amanda, listen, listen.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh.  That's very amusing indeed.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh shut up.  Let go.  I hate you, I hate you.  Do you hear?  You are a conceited and overbearing and utterly impossible.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You are a vile, ill-tempered, loose living, wicked little beast and I never want to see you again as long as I live.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: This is the end.  Do you hear me?  Finally and forever.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You're not going like this.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh.  Yes I am.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You're not.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes I am.   Stop it. Stop it.  Let go of me. Oh.  You're a cruel fiend.  I loathe and I hate you. Marry you again?  Never, never, never. I hope you die in torment, you brute beast cad.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Shut up. Shut up. God, I wouldn't marry you again if you came crawling back to me on a bended knee.  You are a vile, ill-tempered, mean little wench and I never want to see you again as long as I live.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Why did he invite her here?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why does that bother you?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: She's been in New York three and an half years, why all of a sudden?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well maybe...maybe he just wanted to see her.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Nobody comes seven hundred miles just to see.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What do you mean?  You know he lived next door to the girl his whole life, why wouldn't he want to see her?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [BREATHING] You don't look at me like that.  He didn't tell me anything more than he told you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He's not going to marry her.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How do you know he's even thinking about it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's got that about it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh.  So what.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What is going on here, Joe?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Now listen.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: She is not his girl.  She knows she's not.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You can't read her mind.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Then why is she still single?  New York is full of men, why is she still single?  Probably a hundred people told her she's foolish, but she waited.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How do you know why she waited?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Because she knows what I know, that's why.  She's faithful as a rock.  In my darkest moments, I think of her waiting and I know that I'm right.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Hey look, it's a nice day, huh?  Why are we arguing?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Nobody in this house dares take away her faith, Joe.  You know strangers might, but not his father, not his brother.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What do you want me to do? What do you want?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I want you to-- I want you to act like he is coming back, both of you.  Don't think I haven't noticed you since Chris invited her here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I won't stand for any nonsense.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Kate.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Because if he's not coming back, I'll kill myself.  Oh laugh, laugh all you like but why does this happen the very night he comes back.  She goes to sleep in his room and his memorial breaks in pieces.  Look at it, Joe, look.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Calm yourself.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Just believe with me, Joe. Only last week a man came back in Detroit missing longer than Larry.  Believe with me. You, above all, have got to believe. Just believe.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay. Calm yourself.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know. All right, all right. All right. Okay.  Calm yourself. What does that mean, me above all?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Look at you, you're shaking.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I can't help it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What have I got to hide?  What the hell is the matter with you, Kate?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: The craziest thing just happened to me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: This girl; she just offered me fifty thousand dollars to marry her.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Why?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, she's not a citizen so she wants to get a visa.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Is she on the run?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, no, no, no, no, no she just... she's not a citizen but she wants her visa, yeah. She's going to pay me fifty thousand dollars to marry her and stay married to her for two years.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, she just needs to marry you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's incredible. That's awesome. Where's she from?  Maybe you can get a dual citizenship.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That's like twenty five thousand dollar a year for doing nothing. Isn't that awesome?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: She's actually from England, I think.  Well she- she spoke English but she had an accent. I didn't even ask.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's so cool. Uh huh.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER] Why did she pick you? Where were you?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Fifty thousand dollars. Fifty thousand dollars. I was just out... I just... she's - well, she's a friend of friend but like...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You were at a party? And she's like hey. You seem unattached she's like.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.  Can you believe that? Yeah, she's like hey, I'm like sure I'll do it, I don't care. Yeah. I'm like fifty thousand dollars, I'd totally do it for fifty thousand dollars. But the only thing is that's kind of like illegal. So like I could go to jail probably for a long if I get caught, but...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's unbelievable... Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well I've known people who have done this before. Yeah.  You just- it's really fun actually 'cause you have like a fake engagement party and all your friends come over and like...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Have you?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's like I'm really going to get married. We'll have like the whole thing.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, good. [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah. Yeah. And then yeah, and then you know like you could like you could do like like sock her for a lot of money

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know. What do you think I should-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Like make her rent the apartment that you two have to live together in, you know. And you won't pay any rent or you pay like, a hundred bucks a month or something.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh good idea.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.  Make her like open the bank account and stuff too.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's a good idea.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Dude, you lucked out.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know.  Also I get to like plan the wedding now too. That will be fun.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.  My colors are blush and beige what is it, do you know?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Something blue, something new, something... no I don't know. [LAUGHTER] So yeah, wonder if she's going to pay me up front but do you think it's bad though, do you think they're going to like track the money or something?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh I don't know. [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't know get it in cash.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Just cash hardcore.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What should we do?  Where should we get married? We should have party.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How exciting. You should have a wedding on the beach.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah, like a big like- A wedding on the beach, that would be nice.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah, at night.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And then we can honeymoon.  I want to go tropical though like Bahamas- --or like Tahiti or something. I just want to like beach and like drink.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh yeah, absolutely, absolutely.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How exciting.  You should make her bring all your friends too.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'll make her pay for that.  I hear she's like totally wealthy. She's like royalty- --or something like and- --whatever like removed or something but yeah.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [GARBAGE] She's got to be loaded.  fifty thousand dollars.  That's incredible.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Incredible.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm going to marry a blue blood. [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: you're a lucky, lucky, lucky man.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Will you help me plan?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, totally. Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Good.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER] Utterly, utterly ridiculous.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We were very much younger then.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Very much sillier.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Mmhmm.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: However, I do believe the real cause of that row was Peter Burden.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh you knew there was nothing in that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I knew nothing of the sort. You took presents from him.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Presents? It was a trivial little broach.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It was bristling with diamonds in the worst possible taste.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Not at all. It was very pretty. I still wear it often.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You sent out of your way to torture me over Peter Burden.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I did not you worked whole thing up in your jealous imagination.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, you let him kiss you.  You said you did.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, what of it?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What of it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It gave him a lot, a great deal of pleasure and it didn't hurt me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And what about me?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: If you hadn't been so suspicious and nosey you'd never known a thing about it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That's a nice point of view I must say.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm bored with this conversation.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So am I.  I'm bored stiff.  You want some brandy?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, thank you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'll have a little, I think.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't see why you want any you already had two glasses.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, you know no particular reason besides they are very small glasses.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I just think it's silly you know to go on and on and on about such a thing.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You can hardly call three glasses of liquor in a whole evening going on and on and on.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I just, I just think it's becoming a habit with you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Hmm.  Well, you needn't be so grand just because you don't happen to want any at the moment, okay?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Do be quiet.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Really, Amanda.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Don't be stupid, what?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Nothing.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Are you going out somewhere dear?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, darling I'm just making myself fascinating for you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That reply has broken my heart.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well it's a woman's duty to allure the man. Watch me a minute will you?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: As matter the fact that's perfectly true.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh no, it isn't.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes, it is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Don't be stupid, shut up.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know, it's a pity you didn't have any more brandy. It would have made you just a little less disagreeable.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, well that's funny.  It doesn't seem to have worked such wonders with you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know what?  You snap, you snap, you snap you're like a little adder.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Adders don't snap, they sting.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Nonsense.  They have a bag of venom behind of fangs and they snap.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: They sting.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't care.  I don't care, do you understand?  I don't mind if they bark and they roll about like hoops.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Did you see much of Peter Burden after our divorce?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes, I did quite a lot.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I suppose you let him just kiss you or good deal more than too.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, mind you own business.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I suppose you two had a riotous time, huh?  No restrain at all, very enjoyable, he never had much any how.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're quite insufferable, I expect it's because you're drunk.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I am not in the least bit drunk.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You always had a weak head.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I think I told you once before that I had three minute liquor glasses the whole evening long.  A Child of two cannot get drunk on that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: On the contrary, a child two could get violently drunk on only one glass of brandy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh very, very interesting Amanda.  How about the child of uh... four, six or maybe nine---you know, we could work up a splendid little debate about it, you know?  Intemperate tots.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Shut up.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Not very funny darling.  Why don't you have some more brandy?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That's a very good idea I think I will.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Would you uh...turn that off please? You're going to wake the people upstairs.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Why?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: There are no people upstairs. It's a photographer's studio.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well then you'll wake the people downstairs.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: They are away in Tunis.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: This is no time a year for Tunis.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Turn it on again, please.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I will do no such thing.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Very well if you insist on being boorish and idiotic.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Turn it off. It's driving me mad.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I won't.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Turn it off.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Stop it. No. Go away.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Amanda listen. Listen.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: listen Oh I'm sick and tired of listening to you, you damn sadistic bully.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That's very amusing indeed.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh you're cruel you're...you're...I hate you, I hate you. Go away. You're conceited. You're overbearing. You're utterly impossible.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You...You're an evil minded, self-centered little wench and I never want to see you again.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: This is the end do you hear me?  Finally and forever.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You're not going like this.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh yes I am...Oh yes I am. Let go of me. You let go. You...urgh...You're a cruel friend. I loathe and I hate you. Marry you again...Ha...Never, never, never, never. I hope you die in torment. You beast.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No you're not.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Shut up. Shut up. I wouldn't marry you again if you came crawling back to me on a bended knee. You are an evil tempered little vampire and I never want to see you again as long as I live.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What's he going to say, maybe we ought to tell him before he sees it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: He saw it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How could he see it? I was the first one up he was still in bed.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: He was out here when it broke.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: When?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: About four this morning. I heard it cracking and I woke up and looked out. He was standing right here when it cracked.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What was he doing out here at four in the morning?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know. When it cracked he ran into the house and cried in the kitchen.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: So you talked to him?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No. I figured it was best to leave him alone.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He cried hard?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I could hear him right through the floor in my room.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What was he doing out here at that hour? He's dreaming about him again, he's walking around at night.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I guess he is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He's getting just like after he died. What is the meaning of that?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know the meaning of it, but I know one thing mom, we've made a terrible mistake with dad.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Being dishonest with him. I mean that sort of thing always pays off and now it's paying off.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What do you mean dishonest?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know that Larry is not coming back and I know it. Why do we allow him to go on thinking that we believe with him?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What do you want to do, argue with him?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No I don't want to argue with him, but it's about time he realized that nobody believes Larry is alive anymore.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why -- why shouldn't he dream of him? Walk around, waiting for him at night I mean do we contradict him, do we say straight out that we don't have any hope anymore that we haven't had hope for years now?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You can't say that to him.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We've got to say it to him.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Can you prove it, how can you prove it?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: For God sakes it's been three years, nobody comes back after three years, that's insane.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: To you it is and to me. You can talk yourself blue in the face but there is no body and no grave so where are you?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Sit down mom; I want to talk to you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: The trouble is the god damned newspapers, every month or so a boy turns up out of nowhere, so the next one is going to be Larry.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All right. All right. Listen to me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know why I brought Annie here don't you?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I got an idea but what's the story?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm going to ask her to marry me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well that's only your business, Chris.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No it's not only my business.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What do you want me to do; you're old enough to know your own mind.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So it's all right then I'll go ahead with it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, you want to make sure that your father isn't-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: See it isn't just my business-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm just saying

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Sometimes you infuriate me you know that. Isn't it your business to if I tell dad and he throws a fit about it? You have such a talent for ignoring things.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I ignore what I got to ignore. The girl is Larry's girl.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: She's not Larry's girl.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: From father's point of you he isn't dead and you have no right to take his girl.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You can go on from there if you know where to go but I don't know where to go, see I don't know. So what can I do for you?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know why but every time I reach out for something that I really want, I have to pull back 'cause someone else will suffer. My whole bloody life, time after time after time.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're a considerate fellow.  There's nothing wrong with that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: To hell with that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Have you asked Annie yet?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I wanted to get this settled first.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How do you know she'll marry you? Maybe she feels the same way your father does.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, if she does then that's the end of it. From her letters I think she's forgotten him.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know, I'll find out. Then we'll trash it out with dad, right? Mom, don't avoid me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Trouble is you don't see enough women, you never did.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So what I'm not fast with women.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I just don't see why it has to be Annie.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Because it is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's a good answer but it doesn't answer anything. I mean you haven't seen her since you went away to war it's five years.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I can't help it I know her best. I mean lived next door to her my whole life. These years when I think of a wife, I think of Annie.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What do you want, a diagram?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't want a diagram. He thinks he's coming back. Chris, you marry this girl you're pronouncing him dead.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Do you know what's going to happen to your father because I don't, see?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All right. All right. Mom.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Just give it some more thought.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I've given it three years of thought. I thought that if I waited, dad would forget about Larry and we could have a regular wedding and everything happy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: If I can't do that here well, then I'll have to get out.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What the hell is this?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'll get out. I'll get married and go live some place else, maybe New York.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What the hell is this, are you crazy?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I've been a good son too long a good sucker, I'm through with it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What about the business? What is this?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: The business?  The business doesn't inspire me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Must you be inspired?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes, I like it and hour a day. If I'm going to grub for money all day long, at least in the evening I want it beautiful.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I want a family; I want kids; I want something I can give myself to. Annie is in the middle of that. Now where do I find it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Tell me, you'd leave the business?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes, on this I would.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, you don't want to think like that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Then help me stay here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: All right. But you don't want to be thinking like that 'cause otherwise what did we work for, I mean the whole thing is for you, Chris, the whole shooting match is for you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know I know mom. All right. Just help me stay here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Just don't go thinking that way.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, I am thinking that way.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't understand you, do I?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, you don't. I'm a pretty tough guy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yea, I can see that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's almost time for me to go.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I can't believe that--now--are you sure this is absolutely necessary?  Like--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: There's nothing I can do.  I mean, the government you know--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What--what're we gonna do here?  I can't--I can't do this by myself.  I--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're gonna have to.  I mean, you're a great father.  You can do it.  I know you can.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: But, I'm--I'm nothing--I'm nothing without you here.  Maybe we can--we can get out of this somehow.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't think so.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, come on.  You've gotta think of something.  A year--a year away, it's gonna tear us apart.  I don't even--I don't even wanna think about it.  I mean, I don't even know if I'll be able to get in touch with you or--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, we can do the best we can and-and, with um, you know like wireless internet these days--I think that we could-- Talk every once in awhile.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You could send me pictures.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's not going to be the same.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What if--maybe--what if, uh, we went somewhere over there?  I don't--I don't know--I--I need to figure something out for this because--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Their not gonna let you.  You have to stay home and I have to go.  I mean, that's all--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: and--I mean, my daughter--I don't want to put her in danger.  You know?  She has to stay.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: This is gonna be a--a crucial yet--she's--she's growing up.  She's gonna need you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know, but, she needs to be safe more.  She needs to be around kids her age--own age.  She needs to be able to play on the streets and--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: But she's--you're not gonna--you're not gonna be here for--for her first words.  For her first steps.  I mean--it's something that you're supposed to be here for that--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You can just remember it for me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know--I don't know--I don't know how--I don't know how this could even be possible for you--I--if I was--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, I need--I need you to be able to do this for me 'cause I can't do anything about it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I mean, it's just as hard for me, but--I know that we can do it, you know

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I mean, you just get to--go off and do your thing.  I mean, yeah, we're both--I don't know--it's bad for both of us, but--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: ...it would be so much better if we can--if we could stay together somehow.  You know--we could--we could do this together.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't want you in danger.  And I don't want her in danger.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't want you in danger.  Where are you going?  You're going over to war.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I have no choice. There's nothing I can do.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All right.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: As a matter of fact, the real cause of that row was Peter Burden.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Honey, you knew there was nothing in that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I knew nothing of the sort.  You took presents from him.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Presents?  Just a trivial little broach.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Ah, yes, I remember it well.  Bristling with diamonds in the worst possible taste.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, it wasn't.  It was very pretty.  I still have it and I wear it often.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You went out of your way to torture me over Peter Burden.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, I didn't.  You worked the whole thing up in your jealous imagination.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You must admit, he was in love with you, wasn't he?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Just a little perhaps, nothing serious.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You let him kiss you.  You said you did.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, what of it?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What of it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It didn't hurt him at all and I enjoyed it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, what about me?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, if you hadn't been so suspicious and nosey, you never would have known a thing about it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, that's a nice point of view I must say.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm bored with this conversation.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Me, too.  Bored stiff.  You want some brandy?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, thanks.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I think I'll have some.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Don't see why you want any.  You've already had two glasses.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No particular reason.  Anyhow they were very small ones.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Just seems so silly to go on and on and on with such a thing.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You can hardly call three liquor glasses in a whole evening going on and on and on.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, it's become a habit with you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You needn't be so grand, just because you don't happen to want any yourself at the moment.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Don't be so stupid.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Really, Amanda.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Nothing.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Going out somewhere dear?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, just making myself fascinating for you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That reply has broken my heart.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: A woman's job is to allure the man.  Watch me a minute, will you?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: As a matter of fact, that's perfectly true.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, it isn't.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes, it is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, be quiet.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Ah, it's a pity you didn't have any more brandy.  It might have made you a little less disagreeable.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Doesn't seem to have worked such wonders with you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Snap, snap, snap, like a little adder.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Adders don't snap, they sting.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Nonsense.  They have a little bag of venom behind their fangs and they snap.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: They sting.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: They snap.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't care, do you understand?  I don't care.  I don't care if they bark or roll about like hoops.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Did you see much of Peter Burden after our divorce?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes, I did.  Quite a lot.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Hmm, I imagine you let him kiss you a good deal more then.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Mind your own business.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, must have had a riotous time. No restraint at all.  Very enjoyable and never had much anyhow.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're quite insufferable

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I expect it's because you're drunk.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm not in the least drunk.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You've always had a weak head.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: As I mentioned before, I have had three minute liquor glasses of brandy the whole evening long.  A child of two couldn't get drunk on that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: On the contrary, a child of two could get violently drunk on only one glass of brandy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, very interesting.  How about a child of four?  A child of six?  Or a child of nine?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Shut up.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We could get a good debate going about this, don't you think?  Intemperate tots.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Not very funny, dear.  You'd better have some more brandy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All right.  I will.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You better turn that off, I think.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Why?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Because it's late and it'll annoy the people upstairs.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: There aren't any people upstairs.  It's a photographer's studio.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: There are people downstairs I suppose?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: They're away in Tunis.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: This is no time of the year for Tunis.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Turn it on again, please.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'll do no such thing.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Very well, if you insist on being boorish and idiotic.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Turn it off.  It's driving me mad.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You are far too temperamental.  Try to control yourself.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Turn it off.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Stop it.  Go away.  I hate you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Amanda, listen. listen

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Listen?  Listen, indeed.  I am sick and tired of listening to you, damn sadistic bully.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Very amusing, indeed.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I hate you.  Stop it.  Stop it.  I hate you, do you hear?  You're conceited and overbearing and utterly impossible.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You're a vile, tempered, loose living, wicked little beast and I hope to never see you again as long as I live.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: This is the end.  Finally and forever.  Do you hear me?  The end.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You're not going like this.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh Yes, I am.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You're not.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I am.  Let go of me.  You're a cruel fiend and I hate and loathe you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Shut up. Shut up.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I wouldn't-- I wouldn't marry--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I wouldn't marry you if you came in crawling on your knees

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Thank God I realized what you are-- I'd never marry you again ever in my life. You're a cruel fiend and I hate you. You're a beast. You're a beast--I hate you. Stop it.  Stop it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You're a evil vampire and I hope to God I never see you again as long as I live.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Why did he invite her here?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why does that bother you?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: She's been in New York three and half years why all of a sudden-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, maybe he just wanted to see her again.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Nobody comes seven hundred miles just to see.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What do you mean? He lived next door to the girl all his life, why wouldn't he want to see her again?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Don't look at me like that, he didn't tell me any more than he told you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He's not going to marry her.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How do you know he's even thinking of it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's got that all about it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, so what?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What's going on here Joe?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All right. Now, listen kid-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: -She's not his girl Joe; she knows she's not.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You can't read her mind.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Then why is she still single, I mean New York is full of men, why isn't she married? Probably a hundred people told her she's crazy but she's waited.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How do you know why she has waited?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: She knows what I know, that's why. She's faithful as a rock. In my worst moments I think of her waiting and I know again that I'm right.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Look it's a nice day, what are we arguing for?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Nobody in this house dares take her faith away Joe. Strangers might, but not his father, not his brother.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What do you want me to do about it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I want you to act like he's coming back, both of you. Don't you think I haven't noticed since he invited her, I won't stand for any nonsense

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: But Kate

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Because if he's not coming back, I'll kill myself. And laugh -- laugh at me but

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: why did that happen the very night she came back she sleeps in his room and suddenly his memorial breaks to pieces, just look at it, look.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Calm yourself.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I need you to believe with me; I can't stand all alone.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Calm yourself.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Even last week there was a man who showed up in Detroit missing longer than Larry, you read it yourself.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All right. All right. Calm yourself.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Just you above all need to believe.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Wait, why my above all?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Don't stop believing.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What does that mean, me above all?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Look at you -- look at you shaking.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I can't help it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What have I got to hide? What the hell is the matter with you, Kate?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So, how's it going?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's going really well.  Um, I received something in the mail today.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, you got what?  Where?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I got into U.S.C.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, no way.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah, I'm so excited.  So I'm gonna say--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Are you gonna go? you gonna-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah, I think, I mean because where else would I gonna go?  Like the other places that I applied to I really didn't like that much anyway.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: So--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Wow, that's...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: ...that's first choice, huh? That's so awesome and now look you're gonna be--you're gonna be here. you know

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah, I know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Absolutely. I'm so excited.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know.  I know. And we'll all get to hang out.  And I'm--even though we'll be at like at different parts of the city, we can still, like...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: ...hang out and, like, have our different lives--And meet each other's friends and stuff.  So, I'm just so glad 'cause they have such a good school

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah, no, definitely--It's gonna..

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: and like-- The football team--And like all the-...you- what I mean, like...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Fight on.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You can walk somewhere and be anywhere in the country and be like, oh, yeah, I am at U.S.C.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And you know what, you know what I mean, like it's recognizable rather than just being like I went some random school. It's like people really know what you...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Wow. That's cool.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: ...like, they feel like--I feel like it's going to be so like accomplished.  Do you know what I mean?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Like it has some prestige. so

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah. Hey. Prestigious school.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So, what, do you have to send in your deposit now?  Or what you-?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah, I mean there's all the money stuff and my mom's helping me with the financial aid and stuff.  But, it'll be fine--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Like, now that I'm accepted, it's just, like, such a huge load off my mind.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That's great.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't mind worrying about all the paperwork.  You know--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Because, I don't have to like make that decision anymore.  I don't have to try and decide, like, what the bad school I'm going to go to is. you know

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Right.  Right.  Right. Oh, man, then you're going to have to do orientation, I guess.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know. I know.  I think you go and you like stay for a couple of days and you meet people and--And they'll give you like a tour--And show you everything.  Oh, man, I'm just so--I'm so excited.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That'll be awesome.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I mean because you went to the campus before, right?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah, oh totally.  It's a beautiful campus.  It's gonna be really nice.  Um, and everyone is friendly and like there's ivy on all the walls.  Oh, it's just so--it's so like collegiate.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You know what I mean?  Like, it's like exactly what I want.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So what're you--what're you gonna do there?  Have you decided?  Thought about it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, you know, I've thought about it but they have so many things that I might--Like try some things out first...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know.  I mean, it's good all around.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: ...because also on the list of their, um, like G.E.'s or whatever, you have a lot of choices within every single one.  So you can, like, try things out and not just be like, oh, I have to take math, oh, I have to take this.  You know what I mean?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: So, um, so I don't know.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I mean I'm gonna take a bunch of stuff and see.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh man.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I- They have like--they just have so many like prestigious like this school is top ten and like the departments within it, you know what I mean.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I always see people walking around with like U.S.C stuff on--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know, I get to be one of those now--I'll like walk around and be like a U.S.C..  You know what I mean.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know is like.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Ahh. Yeah. [GARBAGE]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You'll be like are you a fan or a student you know? Student. [LAUGHTER] Oh man, that's awesome.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And you'll be like...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Student. I'm a student. Yes I am, Thank you very much.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: A U.S.C. graduate now. You're set.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know.  I'm excited.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, that'll take a while. [GARBAGE]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know, that's a ways down the road. That's cool.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's going to be a lot of work.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: But, it'll be fine, I mean.  I'm so excited. It's going to be so fun.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: In LA. Oh man.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know, and I mean the area's not great, but like the school makes up for it. It'll be fine. It'll be good.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So much.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: But it's LA, you know, everything.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You're getting close to the beach.  I mean geez.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know. I know. So fun.  I can't wait.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Cool.  Well give me a call, you know when--You get in town. definitely Awesome.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I will. I will. Thank you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Thanks.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What's going on?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Kathy died last night.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh my God. Oh my God, I'm so sorry.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: yeah, I mean, you know, it was a -

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I guess we saw it coming and she lasted a lot - a lot longer than, uh, they expected but you know, I mean when it actually happens it's just a lot harder.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It doesn't make any easier, yes.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I mean at least she was home, she wasn't in the hospital anymore,

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, man. I'm so sorry.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: She was with- yeah  She was with Gary, and he said that she was just sitting there and went to sleep, closed her eyes, and that was it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's going to be so rough, I'm sorry.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes. I mean, it's not as rough on me as it is on him but

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: God, it's you know, we've spent so much time with them it's just really surreal, really weird that we're not going to be able to see her anymore and go

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: out to- out to dinner you know and do the troops to California, I mean.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Totally.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's just that- I don't know, it's sort it's sort- of a weird thing you know

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: not being able to see anyone again, who knows where they really went, you know. I mean, I guess we can just hope that wherever they are now if it's anywhere that it's better I mean.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes. Well, at least you have a lot of good memories.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: She was [garbage]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: She really cared about you, you know.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes, I mean she cared about all of us. She was great

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: so loving everybody you know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And she was

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Gosh, I just hate I just hate to see her go.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We were all going take a trip to Europe you know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Even if you still do she'll- she'll be there.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes.  [BREATHING] God.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Are you going to be okay?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I just -- I just don't get it, like there is just nothing you can do about it you know, it's like just out of your control and it

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: just makes it that much harder to deal 'cause as much as you want to, you know, make her better, see her not in any pain, it's like, just I don't know, just has a mind of its own.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Then she's gone.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's going to be okay, I promise.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, you know I appreciate you coming over and talking to me, I mean it definitely helps

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Sure

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: to talk to somebody but

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: you shouldn't be alone

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's just going to take a while, I think.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Ah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Thank you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're the only one I know who loves his parents.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know, it went out of style, didn't it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's all right.  It's a good thing.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You know, it's lovely here, the air is sweet.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You're not sorry you came?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, not sorry.  But, um. But I'm not gonna stay.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: For one thing, your mother as much as told me to go.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You saw that.  I mean and then, well, you've been kind of, um--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, kind of embarrassed ever since I got here.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: The trouble is, I planned on sort of sneaking up on you on a period of a week or so.  But they take it for granted that we're all set.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I knew they would, your mother anyway.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How'd you know?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, from her point of view, why else would I come?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh.  Would you want to?  I guess you know, this is why I asked you to come.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I guess this is why I came.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Ann, I love you.  I love you a great deal.  I love you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I have no imagination.  That's all I know to tell you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm embarrassing you and I didn't want to tell it to you here.  I wanted some place we'd never been before.  A place where we'd be brand new to each other.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You feel wrong here, don't you?  This yard, this chair.  I want you to be ready for me.  I don't want to have to win you away from anything.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, Chris, I've been ready for a long, long time.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And he's gone forever.  You're sure?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I almost got married two years ago.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why didn't you?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, you started to write me
