dialogue.text: You felt something that far back?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Every day since.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Ann, why didn't you let me know?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, I was waiting for you.  I mean, till then you never wrote and when you did, what did you say?  I mean, you can sure be ambiguous sometimes, you know?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Give me a kiss, Anne.  Give me a-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: God, I kissed Annie.  How long--how long I've been waiting to kiss you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'll never forgive you.  Why did you wait all these years?  I mean, all I did was sit and wonder if I was crazy for thinking of you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, Annie, we're gonna live now.  I'm gonna make you so happy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Not like that you're not.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I kissed you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Like Larry's brother.  Do it like you, Chris.  What is it?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Let's drive someplace.  I want to be alone with you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.  What is it, Chris. Your mother?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No.  Nothing like that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, what's wrong?  I mean, even in your letters there was some--something ashamed.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah, I suppose I have been.  But it's going from me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You've gotta tell me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know how to start.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It wouldn't work this way.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's all mixed up with so many other things.  You remember overseas, I was in charge of a company?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah, sure.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, I lost them.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How many?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Just about all.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: gee.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It takes some time for a guy to toss that off.  'Cause they weren't just men.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: For instance, this one time, it had been raining several days and this kid came to me and gave me his last pair of dry socks.  I put them in pocket.  It's only a little thing, but those are the kind of guys I had.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: They didn't die, they killed themselves for each other.  I mean that exactly.  I mean, a little more selfish and they'd have been here today.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I got this idea watching 'em go down.  Everything was being destroyed, see, but it seemed that one new thing was made.  A sort of responsibility.  Man for man. You know what I mean?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: To show that, to bring that onto the Earth again, like some kind of monument and everyone can feel it standing behind him and it would make a difference to him.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Then I came back and it was incredible.  There was no meaning in it here. I mean, the whole thing to them seemed like it's sort of a bus accident.  I went to work with Dad and that rat race again.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And I felt what you said, ashamed somehow 'cause nobody had changed at all.  It seemed to make suckers out of a lot of guys.  I felt wrong to be alive to open the new bank book, drive the new car, see the new refrigerator.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I mean, you can take those things out of a war, but when you drive that car, you've gotta realize that it came out of the love a man can have for a man.  You've gotta be a little better because of it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Otherwise all you have is really loot and there's blood on it.  And I didn't want to take any of that.  And I guess that included you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Do you still feel that way?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I want you now Annie.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: 'Cause you mustn't feel that way.  Because you have a right to everything you have, Chris.  Everything, you understand that?  Me too.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I mean, and your money, there's- there's nothing wrong with your money.  I mean, your father put hundreds of planes in the air.  A man should be paid for that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know Annie.  I'm gonna make a fortune for you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What'll I do with a fortune?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So what do you think?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: About what?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: About what I was just saying.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's ridiculous.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It certainly is not. It is slightly exaggerated scientific fact.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's so P.R. I mean, somebody's giving you a good bill about this wonderful event that's going to happen on the beach.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, I'm not the only one. Look at all these people.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Exactly. Everyone else is told the same thing. It keeps them feeling excited. Keeps them coming back. Keeps them thinking life's going to start at any minute now.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Are we talking about the same thing?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't care. It's still fish to me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Carla, can I ask you something? Don't take this wrong, but are you having your period?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Augie, Goddamn it, don't ask me that. You always ask me that. Why do you ask me that? I hate it. It's insulting.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay, then what's bugging you?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Look, it's-we just-we're looking at this evening in a different way, both of us. We both have different ideas of it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: There's nothing to it, alright? We come down here, the grunion arrive, they do their little fish business, we go ooh, ah, look at the fish, and then they go home and we go home.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's not like that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We're not seeing the grunions?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Look, Augie, we've never seen them. They're never going to come.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We missed them twice. That's not ever.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Twice is as many times as we've tried. That's ever.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We'll see them this time.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, we won't.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's impossible. It's like waiting around. Waiting to see Santa Claus, you know?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Like I feel like my whole life I've been just standing on this beach with my hands clasped waiting for these fish to show up and these fish never show up.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: God, I thought you wanted to see it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I do.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Look, I did. I always do. But it's like every time I try nothing ever happens.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's just fish. Nothing to get traumatized over.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: For God's sake, Augie, this is not about fish.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I've been turning this thing over in my head trying to figure out when the point was when we took a turn for the worse, and I can't seem to pinpoint it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You were fine during the phone call from Marge. Dinner was okay. Doing the dishes was no problem. Let's see. I took a shower. You were watching the news. You said Augie, I think the grunion are running. I said great, let's go. I feel lucky tonight.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And so I'm getting the animals, putting the animals out in the yard. I'm putting on my jacket, getting the car out of the garage-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Do you remember the last time we came here?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: We thought I was pregnant.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You brought a bottle of champagne.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: We took off our shoes and we danced barefoot in the sand. Under the moon.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And you whispered so intimately in my ear so I could feel your words.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, that moment-that was it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I told myself finally, this is how happy I'm supposed to be.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Wait a minute. I got it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Dancing barefoot in the sand. Drinking out of a bottle of champagne.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It was driving past the Knickerbocker Liquor Locker, right? You said let's get some champagne, and I said time's-a-wasting or something like that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You want this to be like the other time, right? That's it. Right?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't want to remember something.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Hope for some things.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Right. I got it. Of course. Listen, do you want to dance?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Do you want me to get some champagne?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Take off our shoes?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, no.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What? What? Do you want me to breathe in your ear?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Do you want to get married again? What? What? Do you want to get a divorce?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: A vacation?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: A new carpet? A poodle?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: A-a back rub, some ice cream, a suicide pact. What the hell do you want, Carla?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I want things to turn out the way that they're supposed to be.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Jesus, welcome to the human race.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Did you think this is how I thought it was going to turn out? Do you think I had some great fantasy down the line? That four years down the line that we'd come to the beach and argue with each other over fish?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, I was just like you. I thought it was going to be all peaches and roses and everything great. And the wind in our hair and the sand in our toes, and the fish will always come and the bills will pay themselves, and we'll have three big fat rosy kids. And oh God.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know what you get? The jokes on us, baby. Because do you know what you get? Huh? Carla? Do you know what you get? You get this.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: This what? What is this? This is nothing.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes, it is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, it's not. It's standing on the beach waiting and fighting.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Right.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Things have never turned out anything the way that I thought they would be.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, I know. Me neither.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I mean, this is, this is everything, and it's a lot, but

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: it's not something else. Do you know what I'm trying to say?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, I'm doing the best I can.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know you are, Augie, and I know you wanted this evening to be nice, but I can't help thinking of being somewhere else.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah, maybe if you were with someone else too.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I didn't say that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, I know. But I know I don't make you happy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Augie, anything I do I'd rather be doing with you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: God, don't you know that? I mean, you're the one that probably wants to be with somebody else. Somebody that didn't take herself so seriously, could enjoy herself more.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Actually now that you mention it, no, I don't.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, I guess we're just in the wrong spart-spot with the right person.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Seemed like a pretty good spot to me. I mean, look at the view of the moon we've got from here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I noticed that. It's beautiful.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You can see right over the water.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: God, big old white moon.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Look what we got here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You brought refreshments?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's not champagne.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: At least we won't need glasses.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Are you still cold? Do you want to go home?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: So I was thinking you might be right.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Maybe this is the right place after all.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm sorry, Augie.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Shh.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: If we're very quiet the fish might come.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Or not.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Or not.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: As a matter of fact, the real cause of that row was Peter Burden.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You knew there was nothing in that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I knew nothing of the sort. You took presents from him.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Presents? It was only a small trivial little broach.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I remember it well. Bristling with diamonds. In the worst possible taste.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Not at all. It was very pretty. And I wear it all the time. I still have it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You went out of your way to torture me over Peter Burden.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, I didn't. You made that up all in your jealous imagination.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You must admit that he was in love with you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Just a little perhaps, but it was nothing serious.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You let him kiss you. You said so.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, what of it?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What of it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh come on, it gave him a lot of pleasure and it didn't harm me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What about me?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, if you hadn't been so suspicious and nosey you'd have never known anything about it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That's a nice point of view, I must say.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, it's true.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Are you bored with this conversation?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I definitely, most definitely am.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So am I. Bored stiff. Want some brandy?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, thanks.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'll have a little, I think.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't see why you want it; you've already had two glasses.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No particular reason. Anyhow, they were very small ones.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't see what's the point of going on and on about something like this.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, my-you can hardly call three minute liquor glasses in the evening going on and on and on.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's become a habit with you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You needn't be so grand just because you don't happen to want some yourself at the moment.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Don't be so stupid.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Really, Amanda.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Nothing.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Going somewhere, dear?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No. Just making myself fascinating for you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That reply has broken my heart.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's a woman's job to allure the man. Watch me, won't you, a minute?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: As a matter of fact, that's perfectly true.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, it isn't.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes, it is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, it's not. I don't care.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's a pity you didn't have more brandy. It might have made you a little less disagreeable.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, it didn't seem to do such wonders with you, now did it?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, snap, snap, snap, like a little adder.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Adders don't snap, they sting.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes, they do. They have a big bag of venom behind their fangs and they snap.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: They sting.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: They snap.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't care. I don't care, do you understand? I don't care if they bark, if they roll over on the floor like hoops.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Uhh,

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: did you see much of Peter Burden after our divorce?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes, I did, quite a lot actually.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I imagine that you let him kiss you quite a bit more then, didn't you?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Mind your business.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You had a riotous-must have had a riotous time. No restraint at all. Very enjoyable. You never had much anyhow.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You are quite insufferable. I suppose it's because you're drunk.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm not in the least bit drunk.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You've always had a weak head.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay. As I mentioned before, I said I had three very minute liquor glasses. That's hardly enough to get a child of two drunk.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: On the contrary, a child of two can get violently drunk on only one glass of brandy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, very interesting indeed. How about a child of four or a child of six or a child of nine. We might have a splendid little debate about this intemperate tots.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Do shut up. Shut up.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't want to talk about this anymore.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You better turn that off.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Why?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's very late and it will annoy the people upstairs.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: There aren't any people upstairs. It's a photographer's studio.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, I suppose the people downstairs then.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: They're away in Tunis.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: This is no time of the year for Tunis.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Turn it on again, please.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, I will do no such thing.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Turn it on.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You've always had far too temperamental for yourself. You should try to control it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Turn it off.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I will not. Go away. Go away. I hate you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, very amusing, indeed. Amanda, listen-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Listen, indeed. No, no, no, no. I am sick and tired of listening to you, you sadistic bully.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Very amusing indeed.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Stop it, stop it, I hate you, I loath you, you are overbearing and conceited and utterly impossible.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know, you're a vile, ill-tempered, wicked little beast and I hope that I never see you again as long as I live.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: This is the end. Do you hear? The end. Now and forever.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, you're not going out like this. No you're not.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, yes I am.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes I am. Let go of me. I hate you and I loath you. God, I can't believe I just finally realized how you are. I am never marry you. Never. Never, never, never. I would rather die in torment.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, shut up. Shut up. Shut up.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I wouldn't marry you again if you came back crawling to me on your hands and knees because you're vile. You're a mean, evil-minded little vampire and I hope to God I never set eyes on you again.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Beast or brute cad, swine beast beast brute.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're the only one I know that still loves his parents.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know.  It sort of went out of style didn't it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.  It's alright.  It's a good thing, you know?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's lovely here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: The air is so sweet.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You're not sorry you came?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.  I'm not sorry.  But I'm not going to stay.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: First of all your mother so much as told me to go.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Look,

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: you saw the way that she acted and then well, I mean, you, you were acting kind of...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, I don't know, embarrassed of her since I came.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well the trouble is I was planning on sneaking up on you over a week or so and they take it for granted that we're all set.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.  I know they would, especially your mother.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How did you know?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well what other reason, from her point of view, would I be coming here?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So, would you want to?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I mean, that's the reason why I asked you here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well,

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh Annie.  I love you.  I love you a great deal.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I love you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I guess that's why I came.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't...I have no imagination that's the only way I know how to tell it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm embarrassing you.  I didn't want to tell you this here.  I wanted to drive someplace brand new where we'd be brand new to each other.  It feels wrong here don't you?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: This yard and this chair.  I don't want to win you from anything, I want you to be ready for me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Look, I've been ready for a long, long time now.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Then he's gone forever, you sure?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Look, I almost got married two years ago.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why didn't you?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You started to write me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You felt something that far back.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Every day since.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why didn't you let me know?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I was waiting for you Chris, I mean, till then you never wrote and then when you did what did you say?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You'd always be so ambiguous.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Give me a kiss Ann, just give me...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh God.  Annie, I kissed Annie.  I kissed Annie.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'll never forgive you for that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How long, how long I've been waiting to do that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I mean,  Why did you wait all these years?  There I was sitting around and wondering if I was crazy for thinking about you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We're going to live now.  I'm going to make you so happy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Not like that you're not.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I kissed you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Like Larry's brother.  Do it like you Chris.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Nothing.  Hey, let's drive somewhere.  I want to be alone with you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What is it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, what is it?  Your mother?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, nothing, nothing like that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Tell me what's wrong.  I mean, even in your letters you seemed ashamed.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, yes I guess I've been ashamed but, it's going from me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You got to tell me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know where to start.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Okay.  It wouldn't work like this?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You remember overseas I was in command of a company?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah, sure.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well I lost them.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How many?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Just about all.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Geez.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Takes a little while to toss that off cause they weren't just men.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: For instance, one time this...it had been raining several days and this one kid, he came up to me, he gave me his last pair of dry socks, put them in my pocket.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That's just a little thing but that's the kind of guys I had.  They didn't just die, they killed themselves for each other and I mean that exactly.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: A little more selfish and they'd still be here today.  And I got this idea watching them go down.  See everything was being destroyed but there was one new thing that was being created.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It was a kind of responsibility, man for man.  You understand me?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And to show that and to bring that onto the earth again like some sort of monument standing right behind all of us and we could feel it and it would make a difference to him.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And then I came here and it was incredible.  There was no meaning in it here.  The whole thing to them was a kind of bus accident.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And I went to work with dad and that rat race again and I felt what you said, ashamed.  Somehow because nobody was changed at all.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It seemed to make a sucker out of a lot of guys.  I felt wrong to be alive.  I felt wrong to have that new checkbook,

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: open that new bank account, drive the new car and see the new refrigerator

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: cause you can take those things out of the war.  But you got to know, when you drive that car that it came out of the love that a man can have for a man and you got to be a little bit better because of that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Otherwise what you have is loot and there's blood on it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And I didn't want to take any of it and I guess that included you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And you still feel that way?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I want you now Annie.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Cause you must not feel that way again.  You hear me?  You can't.  You deserve everything you have Chris.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: that includes me too, I mean and the money, you have right to that money.  Your father put planes up in the air, good planes and he deserves it, you should be proud of that.  A man should be paid for that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [GARBAGE] Annie

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Annie I'm going to make a fortune for you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What am I going to do with a fortune?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Buy some hats?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Hey.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Hey.  How's it going?  I haven't seen you in awhile.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Pretty good Susanna.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What's going on Joe?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Guess who got into U.S.C.?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Um--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Me. Yeah, I did.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No way. Are you serious? Oh my God.  Congratulations. I'm so excited.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I got into the...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I got into cinema production.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.  You didn't get into production.  There's no way.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No.  It's like it's harder than getting into Harvard.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know.  Oh my God.  Oh my God Joe I am so happy for you.  Well you know what that means?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What does that mean?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're going to be here and I'm going to be in LA so we can be together now.  I mean we can be in the same city.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Holy shit...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: We can party.  We can have fun.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: This will be like high school but even better.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.  Hopefully it won't be like high school.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh man I am so proud of you, that is...how did you get...I mean what did you do?  How did you find out or what...?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I-I came home and my mom was like Joe uh-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I have some bad news.  I was like what?  She's like not really you got into U.S.C. and I was like, I was like oh my God.  I was about to tear my own hair out.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh man.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.  This is so crazy.  I mean I didn't get into any other school but I got into the school I wanted.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Did you say yes yet?  I mean have you sent in your answer?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh my God the first minute I got it I sent it back in.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: All right.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: This is so great, you know, because I gone fit on downtown so I'm going to be like right here.  I think I'm going to be living at City Lights downtown.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: This is so exciting.  This is like a new chapter in our lives.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah, it really is.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We're doing what we want to do, then four years later we're going to be working professionals, making money, sipping martinis every day.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: God hopefully.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Man I'm just so happy for you.  I just--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Thank you

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, I'm happy for you but I'm happy for me cause that means you're going to stay.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And tonight my parents want to take me out to sushi and they said I could bring you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh great. I would love to go.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah and they said get whatever you want and...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Mmmm some miso soup.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Some miso soup.  You can get whatever.  You can get a vat full of miso soup.  God.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Ah man.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: This is going to be so great.  I have so many great ideas.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah. Did you...I mean do send in like how long after you send in your application did you hear?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: to start off.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It took them, oh man, it took them like, I mean what it's like April now and any letters that come in April are usually the rejection letters so I was just like...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You were like...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I was struck.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh my God.  I am so proud of you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Why did you invite her here?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why? Does that bother you?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: She's been in New York for three-and-a-half years. She don't just suddenly come and-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, maybe, maybe he just wanted to see her.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You don't travel seven hundred miles just to see.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What do you mean? They lived next door to each other their entire lives. Why shouldn't he want to see her? Hey, don't look at me like that. I don't know anymore than you do.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He's not going to marry her.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How do you know he's even thinking about it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's got that about it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, so what?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What's going on here, Joe?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Listen, kid-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: She's not Larry's girl. She knows that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You can't read her mind.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Then why is she married? Then why isn't she married? She's been in New York and there's hundreds of single men there.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm sure hundreds of them asked her and told her that she's foolish, but no.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: She's waited.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How do you know why she's waited?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Because she thinks like me, that's why.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: She's faithful as a rock, don't you know. In my worst moments I can think of her-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I think again, that I'm-I'm right.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Look, it's a nice day. What are we arguing for?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Nobody in my house better ever dare-dare to challenge her faith. Maybe strangers, but not his father, not his brother.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Calm yourself.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Because he's not coming back. Then what do I got to live for? I'll kill myself.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Calm yourself.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Don't, don't laugh at me, don't laugh at me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Look at it. Because why, when she came here and she slept in his room, the memorial broke into pieces. Look at it, look at it, Joe.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All right. All right. Calm yourself.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You got to believe, believe with me because I can't stand all alone.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay. Just calm yourself.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, you've got to believe.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Believe, Joe. You above all people have got to believe.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why me, above all?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Huh?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why me above all?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You got to keep believing.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Look at you, you're shaking.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I can't help it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What have I got to hide?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Huh? What the hell's the matter with you, Kate?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What's going on man?  What's wrong?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm just so tired all the time.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well have you been trying to get a job, look for a job or...?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I've been looking for like eight months.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know.  It- It's really tough out there.  It's really hard to find a job.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm tired of the same excuses.  No, no you're not qualified enough, wish you had more education.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well what are you looking for?  I mean--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Last time someone told me I was too qualified.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, okay. Well that's--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Cause I went to Harvard.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, that's what?  For what job?  Who...what jobs are you looking for?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I applied as restaurant manager at P.F. Chang.  I applied at----Macy's store manager. Tried to get investment banking job with Deloitte and Touche.  I'm trying everywhere.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: But, Listen--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.  Well it seems to me, you know, you just got to keep going out there, you know, pushing through.  You got a Harvard degree.  I mean, you can get a job anywhere.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know what?  I've been working at temp jobs for the past six months.  You know how degrading it is?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: To be a receptionist?  Oh I spent forty thousand dollar a year for my college degree and I'm a receptionist.  God.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm smarter than half the people I work for.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, what do you...what would ideally like to do, you know?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know astronaut?  I don't know something crazy like that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well what'd you major in?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Biomedical Engineering.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You-You can't be working as a restaurant manager, I mean, come on.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't want to do engineering though.  It's so...I had the internship what, last summer,

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: and I was pulling my hair out and it was like, oh my God.  So I just had to finish the major so now they're like, why are you an engineering major, and why are you working, trying to work at a restaurant.  And it's like I don't know just give me the damn job.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Look I'm sorry-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why all these questions?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You know if you need any help finding a place I can, I can talk to my work you know I work at that law firm downtown and I can ask if they're looking for anybody.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh yeah?  What kind of jobs they got?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I am...just like a law clerk.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't want to be a law clerk.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, I'm moving up.  I mean it could be...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: To be a lawyer?  You go to law school now?  God this is, all these dead ends.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And plus my car is breaking down-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: -they're evicting me from my apartment.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well it doesn't make any sense though.  Like, with a Harvard degree you should be able to--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.  I know.  You'd think I would be able to be C.E.O. of a company right?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Just, you got to hang in there.  Can you ask your parents for help or anybody?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No.  I'm not going to...yeah, they'd laugh in my face.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Just for a little bit, you know?  Cause I-I guarantee you're going to find something.  When you find something it's just going to be huge and you're going to get money.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No. I got a sixteen hundred on my S.A.T..

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Something-- How are you going...?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm freaking----typing sixty words a minute.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How many words a minute?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Sixty words.  Sixty words a minute.  Hey how are you doing Mr. Smith?  Oh, you know, it's just like God, I just want to shoot you Mr. Smith.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Sixty words a minute.  That's a min...a word per min uh second.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.  It's alright.  But--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You could be an amazing receptionist.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm not cut to be a receptionist.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh yeah.  I will be a full time receptionist.  Harvard degree, sixteen hundred on my S.A.T.--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well... If you need something, I mean, you're just going to---can get a temporary thing right now and then look for something--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: --you know? Head of the Science Club.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That's what I've been doing, temporary things

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh I know.  But--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: -it's going to get better I promise you. You just got to hang in there. Everyone, I mean, you know?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Maybe I'll just kill myself.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What?  You can't...what?  Now come on.  Stop it.  Don't be talking like that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I was just joking...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: My, what I would do was just, you know, what about can you call Harvard and see...don't they have connections?  Don't they have like career center and you can find some stuff that's going on?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.  I--they said Brian you're too smart.  You don't need us.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Go out and take over the world by yourself and I'm like what?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well obviously it's not working.  Just cause you got sixteen hundred on your S.A.T. doesn't guarantee you a job.  I mean it should really but--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know.  I don't know.  I know I'm just going to have to keep on looking, keep on searching-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: and I'm never going to find anything probably but I'll just keep working hard at it-- Yeah. Okay.  Positive, I'm going to do good, find that job.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You got to be positive man.  You got to try to just--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: But you got to be real about it.  You have to...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.  I got eighteen hundred on my S.A.T..

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Sixteen hundred.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Same difference.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Twenty-one hundred on my S.A.T..

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Twenty-one hundred?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: But I'm doomed.  Yeah I got so good I was over twenty one hundred.  Now what am I doing?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Like, wow you're really smart we're going to give you an extra [GARBAGE].

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't know, Brian, if they uh--it's been three years.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Hey, you just got to keep on going.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, I don't know, I--maybe this isn't for me. You know, maybe this isn't the right business for me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, don't think like that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I just, I see all these other people getting commercials and work and it's like I'm not getting anything.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I have no money behind me. Nothing. I'm twenty five and--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Russel Crowe wasn't forty until he got his big stuff.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: If you really want to do it-I mean,

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: So I'll have to wait twenty five years-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: you got to do.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: -just going and auditioning and auditioning and rejection after refection, it's like--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You could. You could. We just--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: we're just pooling our funds together.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know, I just don't know if I can handle it. I mean, you're helping me so much financially it's like I can't survive on my own without you. I don't like that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You don't owe me anything.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I feel like I'm not doing anything. Like I'm not giving anything into this world.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You are, you're going to class, you're learning, you're getting better. When you finally get that role you're going to be prepared.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah, but what if I never make it? What if I studied all my life, this theatre, this acting, and I'm never going to get anywhere. I'm never going to be able to have a job.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh my God, Anna, you're still young. Don't even think about that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Time is passing by. Every year it's

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: a part left than I can do.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You're only twenty five, okay? Some people don't start until they're thirty five.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Really?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't know, I just [BREATHING] I get frustrated

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What would you do- What would you do if you didn't? You can go to law school.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's the thing. I don't know. I don't know anything.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Law school? Maybe.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't know. I don't know anything other than this, though, is the problem. This is my life. This is what I built everything about, you know.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: See? So you can't just quit now.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I mean, I could go to law school, but I'm just not passionate about it, you know? Like I'm not--it doesn't drive me, it doesn't motivate me. I--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Have you been going to auditions and stuff?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah. I mean, I get a call-back and stuff, but-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I just, I need a break. I need something to break me out.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How's the job? Still waiting tables at Denny's?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah. Unfortunately.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah, so I go to--get an education for four years and I'm waiting tables at Denny's.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, they tip well.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [BREATHING] Brian-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: it's not funny. I just don't know what I'm going to do.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Maybe you could start teaching. I don't know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah, I guess I could.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Go back to school. You know? Another three more years, get your master's.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Close to thirty. Oof, it's going to be tough.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Thanks.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Hello.  This is Viacom Services.  How can I help you?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Hello?  God finally somebody, look, this is ridiculous.  I've been waiting online for like a half an hour now.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm sorry ma'am, what can I help you with?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Look my, my phone isn't working.  I don't understand what's going on.  I am trying to call out.  I'm not receiving any calls

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: and I need assistance with my...not only is my work phone, it's my home phone and look,

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: this is my business.  This is how I make money is through my phone.  It needs to be working.  Can you please help me?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay.  Can you give me the last four digits of your social security number so I can verify who I'm speaking with?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: two two six six.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay.  And your name is?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Olivia.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Olivia. Um. Okay.  So how long has this problem been?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: This has been going on for the past two weeks.  I called every single day.  Nobody is helping me.  You guys tell me the same thing over and over, call again, call again, call again--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So what exactly is the problem?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't, I don't know what the problem is.  That's what I want you guys to...why is my service not turned on?  And I paid my bills on time.  I don't understand.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Um- I think part of it has to do with the network being down.  It's been having some trouble the last few weeks--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Okay.  Well that is, that is fine and all.  I don't care.  I really don't care because I want my phone to work that's all.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That is I am paying you guys for service and I'm not getting any service.  I get, I get just dropped calls all the time and now it's completely not working at all.  I can't even call out, nine one one probably wouldn't even work.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I understand--we're not-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No.  Okay.  We're not charging you for any of these months.  We're going to give you three months free.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well you better.  You better give me a whole freaking new phone that's what you better do.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We can give you a new phone--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I want a camera phone actually.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We can do that.  We can do that.  You just have to sign a one-year contract though with the--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, no, no...  I'm done with these contract business because this is what can happen.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You sign the contract and then down the line the phone doesn't work and you're stuck, you can't go to a new...no.  No contracts for me.  You give me a new phone.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Besides, it's sort of out of hands at the moment----The whole electrical power outage.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I want to talk to a supervisor

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I would like to talk to your supervisor.  Obviously you're incompetent and don't understand what I'm asking.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Um- Let me connect you to my supervisor.  Actually, he's out right now so I'm supervisor until he comes back. Um-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So you could----speak with me some more, you could call back later on maybe.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's ridiculous.  You know?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No I don't want to call back, you put me on hold for like hours and hours----and it's money, money, money, money and out of my pocket, out of my pocket--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I didn't put you on hold.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: There are a lot of people calling us having problems.  Every phone company is having the same problems ma'am

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Every phone...every single phone company?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Mmm hmmm.  Mmm hmmm.  The power outages, everything, hurricane Katrina. Everything's really messed up.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: This is ridiculous.Well what are we supposed to do?  We starve then because I can't use my phone cause

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I am a realtor and this is my business.  People are calling me all the time but you know, and I don't have a land line.  I can't afford to have a land line

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: don't you-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm really sorry ma'am.  There's not----a lot we can do for it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That you better be sorry.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well you're not helping me at all.  God this is so frustrating.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What I can do for you, if you want to make a call right now I could contact you through our computer.  I can call through my phone and you can speak through me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What?  No.  That's way too complicated.  Look--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: you need to fix my phone.  I don't care what you have to do--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm sorry it has to do with an electrical power outage and stuff--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well then go up the freaking pole and fix it like, you need to help me.  You don't understand I'm in dire, dire need of a phone right now.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, okay I'm going to give you a free phone card that you can use at any payphone and that's on us. Okay?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah yeah, woman going out in South Central on the payphone at night.  Oh that's real safe.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm, I'm sorry you chose to live there um--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, no, no.  I didn't choose to live here.  I work there.  Okay?  Yeah. work work work

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: okay.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well I'm sure maybe there's a phone at work you could use.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: We can't call out.  We can't make out-- line.  I don't work, I work at another office.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: A law firm.  Thank you very much.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All right um--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I work out of my home as a realtor and because I don't have a land line, I need a phone and because of now I don't have one I don't know what to do.  And you're not helping me at all.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: In fact, give me your name sir, what's your name again?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: My name is Sara.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Okay.  Sara what?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Sara Brown.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Sara Brown.  Sara Brown, um- yeah, I'm going to get off the phone with you. And then I'm going to call back and I'm going to give your supervisor your name because you're obviously incompetent to work here.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know maam, we record this conversation so anything you say can be proven in a law of court so keep that in mind.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What are you, what are you a police officer now?  You know, like I'm done, I'm over it.  Goodbye and I hope that you lose your job.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're the only one I know who loves his parents.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know.  It went out of style, didn't it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's okay.  It's a good thing.  You know, it's lovely here and the air is sweet.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So you're not sorry you came?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, not sorry, but I'm not going to stay.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: In the first place, your mother as much as told me to go.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You saw that and then you've been kind of--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, kind of embarrassed ever since I got here.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: The trouble is I planned on sneaking up on you over a period of a week or so.  But they take it for granted that we're all set.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I knew they would, your mother, anyway.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How did you know?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: From her point of view, why else would I come?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well wouldn't you want to?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I guess you know this is why I asked you to come.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I guess this is why I came.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Ann, I love you.  I love you a great deal.  I love you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I have no imagination.  That's all I know to tell you.  I'm embarrassing you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I didn't want to tell it to you here.  I wanted someplace we'd never been; someplace where we'd be brand new to each other.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You think this is wrong, don't you; this yard, this chair?  I want you to be ready for me.  I don't want to win you away from anything.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Chris, I've been ready a long, long time.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Then he's gone forever?  You're sure?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I almost got married two years ago.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why didn't you?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You started to write me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You felt something that far back?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Every day since.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Anne, why didn't you let me know?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I was waiting for you, Chris.  'Til then, you never wrote and when you did, what did you say?  You sure can be ambiguous, you know.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Anne, give me a kiss.  Give me a -

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I kissed you.  I kissed Annie.  How long, how long I've waited to kiss you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'll never forgive you.  Why did you wait all these years?  All I've done is sit around and wonder if I was crazy for thinking of you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Anne, we're going to live now.  I'm going to make you so happy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Not like that you're not.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I kissed you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Like Larry's brother.  Do it like you, Chris.  What is it, Chris?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Let's drive somewhere.  I want to be alone with you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, what is it, Chris?  Your mother?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, no, nothing like that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Then what's wrong.  Even in your letters, there was something ashamed.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes, I suppose there has been.  But it's going from me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You've got to tell me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know where to start.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It wouldn't work this way.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's all mixed up with so many other things.  You remember overseas, I was in command of a company?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah, sure.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well I lost them.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How many?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Just about all.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, gees.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It takes a little time to toss that off because they weren't just men.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: For instance, one time it'd been raining several days.  And this kid came to me and gave me his last pair of dry socks; put them in my pocket.  That's only a little thing, but that's the kind of guys I had.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: They didn't die.  They killed themselves for each other.  I mean that exactly.  A little more selfish and they'd have been here today.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And I got this idea watching them go down, everything was being destroyed, see?  But, to me, it seemed there was one new thing that was made,

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: a kind of responsibility.  Man for man.  You understand me?  And then I went home and it was incredible.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: There was no meaning in it here.  The whole thing to them was some sort of bus accident.  Then I went to work for dad and that whole rat race again.  I felt, what you said, ashamed somehow

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: because nobody was changed.  It seemed to make suckers out of a lot of guys.  I felt wrong to be alive;

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: to open that bank book; to drive the new car; to see the new refrigerator.  I mean, you can take these things out of a war, but when you drive the new car, you have to know that it came out of the love a man can have for a man.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You have to be a little better because of that.  Otherwise, we have is really loot and there's blood on it.  I don't want to take any of it.  I guess that included you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And do you still feel that way?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I want you now, Annie.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Because you mustn't feel that way anymore, Chris.  Because you have a right to everything you have, everything, Chris; to me, too.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And your money, there's nothing wrong in your money.  Your father put hundreds of planes in the air.  You should be proud.  A man should be paid for that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Annie, Annie, I'm going to make you a fortune.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What'll I do with a fortune?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Why did he invite her?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why does that bother you?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's been three years.  Why all of a sudden?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well maybe- maybe he just wanted to see her again.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Nobody comes seven hundred miles just to see.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What do you mean?  He was brought up next door to the girl his whole life.  Why shouldn't he want to see her again?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Don't look at me like that.  He didn't tell me anymore than he told you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: She's not going to marry him.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How do you know he's even thinking about it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's got that about it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well so what.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What's going on here, Joe?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Listen kid.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, line.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Uh, Then why is she still-she's not his girl, Joe

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: She's not his girl, Joe.  She knows she's not.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You can't read her mind.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Then why is she still single?  New York is full of men.  Why hasn't she married?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Probably a hundred people told her she's foolish but she's waited.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How do you know why she waited?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Because she knows what I know that's why.  She's faithful as a rock.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: In my worst moments, I think of her waiting and I know again that I'm right.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Look it's a nice day.  What are we arguing for?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Nobody in this house dares take her faith away, Joe.  Strangers might but not his father, not his brother.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What do you want me to do?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I want you to act like he's coming back, both of you.  Don't think I haven't noticed you since he invited her.  I won't stand for any nonsense.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: But Kate-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Because if he's not coming back, I'll kill myself.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Laugh, laugh at me, but why did that happen the very night she came back?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: She goes to sleep in his room and his memorial breaks in pieces.  Look, look at it.  Joe-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Calm yourself.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Believe with me, Joe.  I can't stand alone.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Calm yourself.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Just last week a man showed up in Detroit missing longer than Larry.  You read it yourself.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Alright.  Alright.  Calm yourself.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You above all have got to believe.  You.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why me above all?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Just don't stop believing.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What does that mean, me above all?  Look at you.  You're shaking.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I can't help it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What have I got to hide?  What the hell is matter with you Kate?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What's he going to say?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Maybe we should tell him before he sees it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: He saw it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How could he see it?  I was the first one up; he was still in bed.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: He was out here when it broke.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: When?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Four o clock this morning.  I heard a crack and I woke up and looked out.  He was standing right over there when it cracked.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What was he doing out here at four o clock in the morning?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He's dreaming of him again, walking around.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I guess he is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's getting to be just like after he died.  What's the meaning of that?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know the meaning of it.  But I know one thing, Mom, you've made a terrible mistake with father.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Being dishonest with him, you know.  This kind of thing always pays off and it's paying off.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What do you mean dishonest?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know Larry is not coming back and I know it.  Why do we allow him to go on thinking that we believe with him?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What do you want to do?  Argue with him?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't want to argue but it's time he realized that nobody believes Larry is alive.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know?  Why shouldn't he walk the nights thinking of him, dreaming of him?   Do we contradict him?  Do we say, we don't have any hope anymore?  That we haven't had any hope for years now?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You can't say that to him.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We've got to say it to him.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Where's the proof?  Do you have any proof?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: For God's sake, three years?  Nobody comes back after three years; that's insane.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: To you it is, to me it is, but to your father, you can talk yourself until you are blue in the face.  But there is no grave and there is no body, so where are you?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Sit down, Mom.  I want to talk to you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's that the trouble is those God damn newspapers.  Every month some new boy comes back and so the next one is going to be Larry, they just--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All right, all right, all right.  You know why I asked Annie here, right?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Why?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well I got an idea, but what's your story?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm going to ask her to marry me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well that's only your business, Chris.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know it's not just my business.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well what do you want me to do?  You're old enough to know your own mind.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So all right then, I'll just go ahead with it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well you want to make sure that your father is not going to --

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Then it's not just my business.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm just saying.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know sometimes you infuriate me.  you know that?  Isn't it your business if I tell father and he throws a fit about it?  God, you have such a talent for ignoring things.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh.  I ignore what I got to ignore.  That girl is Larry's girl.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: She's not Larry's girl.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: From your father's point of view, he is not dead and- Chris he still thinks he's still alive.  The girl is Larry's girl.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Now you can go on from there if you know where to go, but I'm telling you, I don't know where to go.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know why it is, but every time I reach out for something I have to pull back because I am afraid other people will suffer. My whole bloody life, time after time.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're a considerate fellow, there's nothing wrong in that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: To hell with that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I just don't see why.  Have you asked Annie yet?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I wanted to get this settled first.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well how do you know she's going to marry you?  Maybe she feels the same way your father does.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well if she does, then that's it.  That's the end of it.  From her letters, though, I think she's pretty much forgotten him.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And then we'll thrash it out with father.  Okay Mom?  Don't avoid me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: The trouble is you don't see enough women.  You never did.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So what.  I'm not fast with women.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Why does it have to be Annie?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Because it is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh that's a great reason.  It's no reason at all.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You haven't seen her since you went away to war, it's been five years.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I can't help it, I know her best.  I was brought up next door to her, you know?  These years when I think of someone for my wife, I think of Annie.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Mom, what do you want?  A diagram?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't want a diagram.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He thinks he's coming back Chris.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You marry that girl, you are pronouncing him dead...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: ...and then what's that going to do to your father?  Do you know?  I don't.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All right, then, Mom. [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Just give it some more thought.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I've given it three years of thought.  And I'd hope that if I waited, father would forget about Larry and then we could just have a regular wedding and everyone would be happy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: But if I can't do that here, I may have to go somewhere else.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What the hell is this?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'll get out.  I'll get married and I'll move somewhere else, maybe New York.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Are you crazy?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I've been a good son for too long, a good sucker.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You have a business here.  What the hell is this?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: The business?  The business doesn't inspire me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh.  Must you be inspired?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes.  I like it for an hour a day.  I don't care if I have to grub for money all day long, when I come home I want it happy.

dialogue.speaker: M

dialogue.text: On this, I would.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well you don't want to think like that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Then help me stay here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: All right.  But you don't want to think like that because what the hell are we working for, Chris?  It's all for you.  This whole shooting match is for you.

dialogue.text: I know that.  Then just help me stay here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Just don't think like that.

dialogue.text: Well I am thinking like that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't understand you, do I?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No.  You don't.  I'm a pretty tough guy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I can see that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Excuse me.

dialogue.text: Do you have your forms?

dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.text: Let me see them.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Is there a problem?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You were standing at the beginning and you directed me.

dialogue.text: Well what's the problem?  Let me change it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: This form is a Z.X.four.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You can't--  This is not the line for Z.X.four.  If you're going to fill out the Z.X.four, you need to have a different form of ID.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No. I need another set of ID to prove this is actually you.

dialogue.text: How am I supposed to get an ID without an ID?  How does a person get an ID in the first place?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know.  But I need an ID to pass this form along.  I can't just send it along without an ID.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm here to get an ID.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No.  I need another ID, a separate one.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Like what?  Like a birth certificate?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: A birth certificate, a passport...a student ID; didn't you go to school?  Anything?

dialogue.text: Who the hell has a birth certificate?

dialogue.text: Yes but my wallet was stolen, I don't have anything.  I don't have any credit cards, I don't have my ID.  Don't you have things on file here?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.  We keep it on file, but we need an ID to access that file.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's out of control.

dialogue.speaker: M

dialogue.text: How long have you been working here?

dialogue.text: Clearly.  You know, do you have like a supervisor or something?

dialogue.text: That would - I would appreciate that.  Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M

dialogue.text: I wonder.

dialogue.text: We are okay, aren't we darling?

dialogue.text: Now and always, sweet.

dialogue.text: It had to happen sooner or later.

dialogue.text: We'll behave exquisitely.

dialogue.speaker: M

dialogue.text: I think I shall do a curtsy.

dialogue.speaker: F

dialogue.text: [GARBAGE]

dialogue.text: Uh huh.
