dialogue.text: Pass what up?  I mean these fish swim out of the ocean, they flop around on the beach, they swim away and then they die.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.  But this..this moment on the beach is like the highlight of their little lives.  All that flopping around is laying eggs or what to do - spawning or mating or whatever.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: This is a big night for these little guys.  It's like life's last orgy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't see why you're so excited; this isn't a freaking moon landing we are talking about.  It's fish.  It's a fish nobody even eats.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah they do.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh Augie

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: okay... well, Whatever.  But it's a fish who do something no other fish do.  It's like those swallows returning to Capistrano or like those lemmings that throw themselves off the cliffs.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: There's like mystery here, there's magic.  It's like a little bit of the unexplainable.  I just can't see how you're not interested.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm just not.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: For real?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: God, I don't get it.  you know the first time we came here, you said it was the best night of your life?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And last year, I remember distinctly you said, you were so excited to get here that you don't remember you stubbed your toe until we were in the car.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Last time, you'll also remember, we got our shoes wet, I got sand in my panties, you got a sore throat and we got into a big fight and we did not see the grunions.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Ahh...we weren't in a good spot.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Hmm.  We didn't see them the year before either.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We just weren't in a good spot.  I'm telling you, this is a much better spot.  I have instincts for these things.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Look there, see?  What's that?  No, that's - that's just seaweed.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: God, this is great.  Think about this.  I know you are not interested, but just think about this.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Right now out there, there is this mass of silver fish and it's heading this way.  No one sent them an invitation, no one told them, no one even gave them a map.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Just all at once, they turned and they formed this line as long as the California coast.  And some instinctual little firecracker went off in their bodies and they all just turned as one and started swimming.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: They are swimming right now.  They are swimming as if that is the only thing that matters to them.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's single mindedness with no mind.  It is urgency that is just pure urge.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And they are swimming right now to this very point where we stand for this huge celebration of sex and death.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh look.  I'm giving myself goose bumps, my hairs are standing up on my arm.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's the wind.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So what do you think?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: About what?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: About all of that, about all I was talking about.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What he's going to say?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: He saw it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: When?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: He was out here at four this morning.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How could he see it?  I was the first one up and he was still in bed.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I was out here at four this morning I heard a crack and I looked out the window and he was standing right over there.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What was he doing here at four in the morning?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know.  But he went back in the kitchen and he cried.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Did you talk to him?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No.  I figured I'd just let it wait.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Cried hard?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah, I could hear him crying through the floorboards in my room.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What is he doing out here at that hour?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He's dreaming about him again, walking the streets.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I guess he is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's getting to be just like after he died.  What is the meaning of that?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know the meaning of it.  But I know we've made terrible mistake with father.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I mean, these kinds of things, man they always come back at you.  And this is definitely coming back to us.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What do you mean a mistake?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I just--why shouldn't he walk the nights waiting for him, huh?  Do we contradict him do we say we don't have any hope any more that he's not coming back?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What do you want to do, argue with him?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't want to argue with him, it's just for God's sake it's time he realized that no one believes with him any more.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You can't say that to him.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I got to.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What, can you prove it?  What proof do you have?  Can you prove it?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: For God's sake, three years?  Nobody comes back after three years. It's insane.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: To you it is, to me it is.  But to your father?  You can talk yourself 'til you're blue in the face but there's was no grave and there is no body.  So where are you?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay, all right.  Mom, sit down.  I want to talk to you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: The trouble is those god damn news papers.  Every month some boy comes back missing longer then Larry so--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah, okay all right, all right.  Listen, um, you know why I asked Annie here, right?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Why?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, I've got an idea but what's the story?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm going to ask her to marry me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, that's only your business, Chris.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know it's not just my business.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, what do you want me to do?  You're old enough known your own business.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So it's okay then?  I'm just going to go ahead with it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You want to make sure that your father's not going to...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: See.  Then it's not just my business. Sometimes you infuriate me, you know that?  You know it's just your business too if I tell father and he throws a fit about it, huh?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm just saying.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm sorry.  I ignore what I've got to ignore. That girl is Larry's girl.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: She is not Larry's girl.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: From father's point of view he is not dead and you have no right to take his girl.  I'm just saying that you can go on from there if you know where to go but I'm saying I don't know where to go.  See, I don't know.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know why it is you know every time I reach out for something I have to pull back 'cause I'm afraid it's going to hurt somebody.  All my life...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're a considerate fellow.  There's nothing wrong in that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: To hell with that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Did you ask Annie yet?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, I wanted to get this all sorted out first.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, how do you know she's going to marry you?  Maybe she feels same way your father does.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, if she does then that's the end of it.  However from her letters I think she's pretty much forgotten him.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: The trouble is you don't see enough women, you never did.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So what?  I'm just--I'm not fast with women.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't see why it has to be Annie.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Because it is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's a good answer but it doesn't answer anything.  You haven't seen her since you went away to war, it's been five years.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know, it I think of her, I grew up next to her.  She is what I think of when I think of a wife.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He thinks he's coming back, Chris.  You marry that girl you're pronouncing him dead.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Do you know what that'll do to you, to your father, do you know?  I don't.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All right then.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Give it some more thought.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I've given it lots of thought.  And I keep coming back to the same thing.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: When I think of a family, when I think of my future I see Annie in the center of that and you know and if that can't happen here then I'll go somewhere else.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What the hell is this?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'll leave.  I'll get married and move somewhere else maybe New York.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Are you crazy?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'll do it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You have a business here.  I said what the hell is this?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Business?  The business doesn't inspire me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, must you be inspired.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes, yes I like it for one hour a day.  I don't care if I have to grub for money all day long when I come home I want it nice, I want a family, I want to kids and Annie is in the center of that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: If that can't happen here...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You mean to tell me you would leave the business for this.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes, on this I would.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, you don't want to think like that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Then help me stay here mom.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: All right but you don't think like that because what the hell is this all for.  This is all for you, what are we working for Chris? The whole shooting match is for you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know, I know.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Then help me stay.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, you don't think like that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I am thinking like that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't understand you, do I?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, you don't.  I'm a pretty tough guy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, I can see that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Did you get the letter?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes.  There's a big envelope it says, you're in. I know.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah. That is so awesome.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh my God. What are you going to do? [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: So I have to move back to the ghetto but...I know.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh-Yeah, I bet you're really excited. Oh.  That's what loans are for?  Right? Exactly.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm really excited.  Yeah. I don't know how I'm going to pay for anything, but... I also- Yeah.  Loans, too, yeah. I applied, though, for a bunch of grants and scholarships so I'm still waiting to hear on that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh.  Good, good.  That's awesome. Are you going to stay around here?  Or are you going to like get a different neighborhood- you going to move to a different neighborhood?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh- I know, I know, I know, I know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't know.  I spend so much time commuting as it is, I'd rather.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: This is so- I am so happy that you're going to stay.  You're not going to...We should totally throw a party.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know. We should throw a party.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: At Arapaho we could afford that. [GARBAGE]. Yeah.  So what are you doing this summer, though?  You're staying around, too, yeah?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: A rapper party ho. Yeah. Okay.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I am just- Yeah.  I'm sticking around, I'm just doing my thing.  I'm living here.  I'm so glad you're going to stay, I'm so glad you're going to be here. Yeah. Woo.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's a relief too. I mean I was thinking I was going to have to pack up all of my stuff but yeah. Hooray for U.S.C.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.  Big time.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Mmhmm. Mmhmm. Yay. So what major?  What are you doing?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Umm. It's...It's uhh...It's Critical Studies. It's a really prestigious program, so they say.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, okay.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Ooh. Fancy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.  I'm not sure.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Is this a Masters or a P.h.D.?  Or can you...? Nice

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Umm...P.h.D. [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That's good.  Don't you have to like teach a class, too, when you do that?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Um, yeah, yeah.  I'm a TA for two sessions. Mmhmm.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Teacher. Mrs. Nash, I have a question.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: So I get to mold young minds. Mrs.?  That's my mother.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You have to get married.  Well you are married to Chuck.  You're Mrs. Nash.  Not to be confused with Mrs. Dash which is the popular seasoning.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I would be like- Oh. Right, right, right.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Mrs. Nash.  That's so awesome, though.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah. Yeah I'm excited. Hooray.  And then I'll be a millionaire once I graduate, you understand? Because that's the way it works.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yay...School's fun.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Of course, right.  That's where the real money is, being a student.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.  Totally. [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That's how you get the big bucks.  Are you messing with the chair? Don't ruin it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know. I made such a mess of it, the entire time.  The last three things I've done, I've ruined everything, I think. Mm-hmm.  Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Hey, Joy come in here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What's happening?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I have to go back.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I just got a letter I have to go back.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: When?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: First thing tomorrow morning.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Are you kidding me?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't understand, I don't underst--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How can they do that?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: They can do it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: They said you're home for at least four years.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I guess they can do it,

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: The National Guard is I guess really spread thin and then everyone has to go.  We all have to go back, my whole companies going back.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's not fair.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I can't believe it. I just got back.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So yeah, we leave tomorrow...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: ...we're all shipping out.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I just got I feel like I'm in shock actually.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't even know what to tell you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What about the birthday party?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I guess you're just going to have to have it without me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Hey listen, it's going to be okay though, all right?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You're going to be fine.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Me?  I'm not worried about me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm going to be fine too, okay?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How do you know?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know I have a good... I have a really good group of guys with me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We're going to be okay.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're going with the same ones?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Do promise me you're going to take a lot of pictures.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Always, I always do.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's not the same though.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I just wish there was something I could do.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: We could hide away.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Run away?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Mm hmm.  We'll build a bunker and never come out.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I really don't want to go, I don't want to go...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER] Mmm.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm scared.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Don't say that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'll send you a letter every single day.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I love you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I love you too.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Can I help you?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes, please help me.  Where is my bag?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I need a little more information.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Where is my bag?  Come on, I've been here for four hours.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What- What flight did you come in on?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay, I'm coming in from Atlanta.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Georgia?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes, Georgia.  Good for you I need my bag.  Can you...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: There's no need for you to raise your voice, sir.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I've been college educated.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I speak your language.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Are you insinuating that I don't have a college education and that- for some reason that makes you a better person than I am?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Listen, shut your smug mouth, okay?  I don't need that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm just saying you don't need to talk to me like I-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I've been sitting here for four hours.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm not a child.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I've been here for sixteen.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You people have just been tossing me around like a used hanky.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I come here every single day.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You work here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Details, Details.  Well, anyhow can I--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: so you flew in from Atlanta...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: My bag from Atlanta.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Four...Four hours ago.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's a little black bag with wheels.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Do you have any i-?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That you wouldn't let me put in the overhead compartment.  You said I had to check it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I wouldn't let you?   I was not in Atlanta. I was not in Atlanta.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's a tiny little bag.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I had nothing to do with the boarding attendance.  I'm sorry that your seat was wherever it was.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It was right in the middle of five different people.  I had a huge fat lady next me, a crying kid on left I went like can I please get a Bloody Mary, please? Will you bring a Bloody Mary?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I have some unfortunate news, uh, that your bag isn't going to be--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: --arriving any time soon.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Just had a really, really stressful day, okay?  And I need my bag; can you please help me get my bag?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm really sorry to tell you this but...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's not.  I can offer you fifty dollars and a reimbursement gift cards for our airline...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: ...and your future...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm sorry, wait a minute.  Are you saying I'm not going to get my bag at all?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's gone.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Where is it?  Where did it go?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: We've actually...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You mean did someone steal it? Do people steal bags?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: They do as matter of fact.  We don't like to publicize it because

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: people wouldn't Fly our airline.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Probably people that work for your company huh?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Do you know what was in that little bag that I could have just easily put in overhead compartment but no I had to check?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What was that?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: My computer which has all of my data which I'm collecting right now.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's unfortunate.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah it's really unfortunate you know why because I'm going to get fired if I don't get that.  So I need to have that back.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's too bad.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Fifty dollars is not going to cover me for my job, okay?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I wish I could give it to you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well you need to find it. Can I just go back there and look through the bags?  Can I just go back there and just go through maybe I'll find it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I wish I-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's not - no.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It'll be a lot more than what you're doing sitting here and just give me lip service.  I'd like to go back at least do some aggressive searching for my stuff.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: We have plenty of aggressive searching going on it's not there.  Someone's taken it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Sure, yeah right you have plenty of aggressive searching going on, aggressive searching, drinking coffee and smoking cigarettes.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know what you guys do when you're not working you're union people; you just sit around on your ass.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You know I don't need to take this sort of abuse.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, I don't need to take this kind of abuse either.  I just was trying get back to Atlanta. I just got home, I just want to get my bag and get my stuff. And keep my job.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's fantastic.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Then why don't you take your fifty dollars. Get yourself a taxi and go shopping tomorrow.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Thank you very much.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Did you get the letter?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes.  There's a big envelope it says, you're in. I know.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah. That is so awesome.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh my God. What are you going to do? [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: So I have to move back to the ghetto but...I know.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh-Yeah, I bet you're really excited. Oh.  That's what loans are for?  Right? Exactly.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm really excited.  Yeah. I don't know how I'm going to pay for anything, but... I also- Yeah.  Loans, too, yeah. I applied, though, for a bunch of grants and scholarships so I'm still waiting to hear on that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh.  Good, good.  That's awesome. Are you going to stay around here?  Or are you going to like get a different neighborhood- you going to move to a different neighborhood?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh- I know, I know, I know, I know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't know.  I spend so much time commuting as it is, I'd rather.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: This is so- I am so happy that you're going to stay.  You're not going to...We should totally throw a party.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know. We should throw a party.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: At Arapaho we could afford that. [GARBAGE]. Yeah.  So what are you doing this summer, though?  You're staying around, too, yeah?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: A rapper party ho. Yeah. Okay.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I am just- Yeah.  I'm sticking around, I'm just doing my thing.  I'm living here.  I'm so glad you're going to stay, I'm so glad you're going to be here. Yeah. Woo.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's a relief too. I mean I was thinking I was going to have to pack up all of my stuff but yeah. Hooray for U.S.C.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.  Big time.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Mmhmm. Mmhmm. Yay. So what major?  What are you doing?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Umm. It's...It's uhh...It's Critical Studies. It's a really prestigious program, so they say.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, okay.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Ooh. Fancy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.  I'm not sure.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Is this a Masters or a P.h.D.?  Or can you...? Nice

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Umm...P.h.D. [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That's good.  Don't you have to like teach a class, too, when you do that?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Um, yeah, yeah.  I'm a TA for two sessions. Mmhmm.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Teacher. Mrs. Nash, I have a question.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: So I get to mold young minds. Mrs.?  That's my mother.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You have to get married.  Well you are married to Chuck.  You're Mrs. Nash.  Not to be confused with Mrs. Dash which is the popular seasoning.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I would be like- Oh. Right, right, right.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Mrs. Nash.  That's so awesome, though.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah. Yeah I'm excited. Hooray.  And then I'll be a millionaire once I graduate, you understand? Because that's the way it works.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yay...School's fun.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Of course, right.  That's where the real money is, being a student.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.  Totally. [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That's how you get the big bucks.  Are you messing with the chair? Don't ruin it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know. I made such a mess of it, the entire time.  The last three things I've done, I've ruined everything, I think. Mm-hmm.  Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What's he going to say?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Maybe we should tell him before he sees it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: He saw it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How could he see it?  I was the first one up; he was still in bed.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: He was out here when it broke.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: When?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Four o clock this morning.  I heard a crack and I woke up and looked out.  He was standing right over there when it cracked.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What was he doing out here at four o clock in the morning?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He's dreaming of him again, walking around.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I guess he is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's getting to be just like after he died.  What's the meaning of that?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know the meaning of it.  But I know one thing, Mom, you've made a terrible mistake with father.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Being dishonest with him, you know.  This kind of thing always pays off and it's paying off.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What do you mean dishonest?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know Larry is not coming back and I know it.  Why do we allow him to go on thinking that we believe with him?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What do you want to do?  Argue with him?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't want to argue but it's time he realized that nobody believes Larry is alive.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know?  Why shouldn't he walk the nights thinking of him, dreaming of him?   Do we contradict him?  Do we say, we don't have any hope anymore?  That we haven't had any hope for years now?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You can't say that to him.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We've got to say it to him.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Where's the proof?  Do you have any proof?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: For God's sake, three years?  Nobody comes back after three years; that's insane.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: To you it is, to me it is, but to your father, you can talk yourself until you are blue in the face.  But there is no grave and there is no body, so where are you?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Sit down, Mom.  I want to talk to you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's that the trouble is those God damn newspapers.  Every month some new boy comes back and so the next one is going to be Larry, they just--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All right, all right, all right.  You know why I asked Annie here, right?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Why?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well I got an idea, but what's your story?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm going to ask her to marry me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well that's only your business, Chris.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know it's not just my business.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well what do you want me to do?  You're old enough to know your own mind.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So all right then, I'll just go ahead with it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well you want to make sure that your father is not going to --

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Then it's not just my business.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm just saying.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know sometimes you infuriate me.  you know that?  Isn't it your business if I tell father and he throws a fit about it?  God, you have such a talent for ignoring things.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh.  I ignore what I got to ignore.  That girl is Larry's girl.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: She's not Larry's girl.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: From your father's point of view, he is not dead and- Chris he still thinks he's still alive.  The girl is Larry's girl.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Now you can go on from there if you know where to go, but I'm telling you, I don't know where to go.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know why it is, but every time I reach out for something I have to pull back because I am afraid other people will suffer. My whole bloody life, time after time.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're a considerate fellow, there's nothing wrong in that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: To hell with that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I just don't see why.  Have you asked Annie yet?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I wanted to get this settled first.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well how do you know she's going to marry you?  Maybe she feels the same way your father does.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well if she does, then that's it.  That's the end of it.  From her letters, though, I think she's pretty much forgotten him.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And then we'll thrash it out with father.  Okay Mom?  Don't avoid me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: The trouble is you don't see enough women.  You never did.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So what.  I'm not fast with women.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Why does it have to be Annie?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Because it is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh that's a great reason.  It's no reason at all.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You haven't seen her since you went away to war, it's been five years.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I can't help it, I know her best.  I was brought up next door to her, you know?  These years when I think of someone for my wife, I think of Annie.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Mom, what do you want?  A diagram?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't want a diagram.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He thinks he's coming back Chris.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You marry that girl, you are pronouncing him dead...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: ...and then what's that going to do to your father?  Do you know?  I don't.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All right, then, Mom. [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Just give it some more thought.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I've given it three years of thought.  And I'd hope that if I waited, father would forget about Larry and then we could just have a regular wedding and everyone would be happy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: But if I can't do that here, I may have to go somewhere else.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What the hell is this?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'll get out.  I'll get married and I'll move somewhere else, maybe New York.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Are you crazy?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I've been a good son for too long, a good sucker.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You have a business here.  What the hell is this?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: The business?  The business doesn't inspire me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh.  Must you be inspired?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes.  I like it for an hour a day.  I don't care if I have to grub for money all day long, when I come home I want it happy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I want some kids, I want a family, I want somebody that I can give myself to and Annie is in the center of that.  Now it's just where to find it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You mean to tell me that you would leave the business over this?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: On this, I would.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well you don't want to think like that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Then help me stay here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: All right.  But you don't want to think like that because what the hell are we working for, Chris?  It's all for you.  This whole shooting match is for you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know that.  Then just help me stay here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Just don't think like that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well I am thinking like that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't understand you, do I?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No.  You don't.  I'm a pretty tough guy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I can see that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm sorry, Joy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's okay.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Is there anything I can get you?  Do you want me to take care of anything for you or...?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, no, no.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: ...pick up anything?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know you are welcome to stay at my house if you want to just check out for a couple days and hang out.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's sweet.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Thank you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I went to see her headstone a week or two ago.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I used to go to cemeteries a lot before she died.  I just, you know, I felt like they were urban oasis, you know, there is always this green in the city.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Hmm.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: So I was like wandering around before.  It takes forever to find her headstone; I always lose it. You know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: So I was looking at this other one and there was like a piece of candy there and I thought that I would take the candy and put it on her headstone.  And-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: this woman came up and, you know, it was hers. It was her person that was there.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh.  She was there?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.  And she was like, that's pathetic, I hope you enjoy it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And I, you know, I mean, I said I was sorry and I brought it back to her kind of and I like put it on the ground and she was like, no, it's fine.  She was like, I would rather have her back, honestly.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Mmhmm.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't know.  It just, like, I felt so bad because I shouldn't have done it.  I don't know.  Whatever.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't know.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How long were you there for?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: At the cemetery?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Mmhmm.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: couple hours.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I brought- I brought Chuck with me. He went to Redlands, yeah, for the day.  We ran through the sprinklers.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh really?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You ran through the sprinklers in the cemetery?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It was hot.[LIPSMACK]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Is it a big cemetery?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.  It's huge.  Redlands is an old city so they have lots and lots of stones.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, so they're like really old too, really old ones?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's weird.  Whenever I go back to town, I think of her.  I mean, it's like ... I mean we grew up together and she died when we were twenty one.  And yeah.  She had cancer, she had two brain tumors.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: My best friend Heather.  She's got a- we have a- we built this like little--  There's a park, Prospect Park.  And there is like a garden section of it that we set up for her.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: She used to have these poetry parties on Memorial Day.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Mmhmm.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Umm. Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And the last time before she died, I remember she couldn't really stand, umm...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: But I mean she could, but it was- so it was kind of sitting at her feet holding her up and she had these poems she had memorized.  And I remember looking up, she had curly red hair and there was this palm tree right behind her and it was like a crown growing right out of her head.  It was cool.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Mmhmm.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Some, I guess.  She memorized this one, John Dunn, it's called, Death Be Not Proud. and-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So she wrote a lot of poetry?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: There's another one, I can't remember.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I remember, too, when we were--  she died at U.C.L.A.  She had brain surgery and there was not much hope to begin with, but I gave blood for her surgery, her mom and I before, so we dropped her off in the waiting room and then we were giving blood and came back.  And she, in her wheelchair, like can hardly do anything, reciting her poetry for these people like in the waiting room.  All she needs is a God damn audience.  You know?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Mmhmm.Mmhmm.Mmhmm.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What time is it?  I think it's supposed to run around midnight, right?  God, this is great, isn't it, Carla?  Look at this night we got here, huh.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Actually I want to get a little further up the coast, get away from all like the lights and the people, but...  How are you doing?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Fine.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay.  Is that, is that--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No.  That's just foam.  I don't know.  I can't tell.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know, probably if you can't tell, though, it's probably not them, right?  It's probably going to be like this unmistakable thing, right?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh no.  you know what I forgot?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: My flashlight.  God, how could I be so stupid?  I can't believe I forgot my flashlight.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What flashlight?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: The flashlight, the silver one.  There's only one, isn't there?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's not your flashlight.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Whose is it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's ours; it's my flashlight too.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh...well. Yeah, of course.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You keep saying my flashlight like it's just yours.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How's that supposed to make me feel?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Of course, our flashlight.  What's yours is mine.  Me flashlight es su flashlight.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Naturally.  God, how could we not think to bring it?  I hope the moon stays out, though.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Do they always run during a full moon?  I don't remember.  Was it full last year?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Huh.  Are you cold?  Do you want my jacket?  No?  you know, we should have brought the blanket?  Our blanket.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Aw.  Do you know, I should have brought a six pack, too.  A six pack, that would be just the ticket right about now.  Huh?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: God, I'm so excited, I'm like a kid.  I can't believe I got out of the house with my fly zipped up.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I wonder if they can hear me talk or like feel the vibrations in the sand when we move around.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm cold.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Do you want my jacket?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's after eleven, let's go.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What?  We just got here.  What's the point of coming all the way down here if we just turn around and go home?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: There is no point.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Right.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's my point.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Wait, that's my point, too.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, then let's go.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, no.  Okay.  That's not my point.  My point is there is no point in coming down here if we just turn around and go home.  Don't you want to see it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Not particularly.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why not?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I just don't.  It's stupid.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Honey, this is like a natural phenomenon. I mean... People in Kansas would have to get plane reservations and get hotel rooms to see this.  It's just forty minutes away for us; it's too good to pass up.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Pass what up?  I mean these fish swim out of the ocean, they flop around on the beach, they swim away and then they die.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.  But this..this moment on the beach is like the highlight of their little lives.  All that flopping around is laying eggs or what to do - spawning or mating or whatever.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: This is a big night for these little guys.  It's like life's last orgy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't see why you're so excited; this isn't a freaking moon landing we are talking about.  It's fish.  It's a fish nobody even eats.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah they do.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh Augie

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: okay... well, Whatever.  But it's a fish who do something no other fish do.  It's like those swallows returning to Capistrano or like those lemmings that throw themselves off the cliffs.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: There's like mystery here, there's magic.  It's like a little bit of the unexplainable.  I just can't see how you're not interested.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm just not.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: For real?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: God, I don't get it.  you know the first time we came here, you said it was the best night of your life?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And last year, I remember distinctly you said, you were so excited to get here that you don't remember you stubbed your toe until we were in the car.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Last time, you'll also remember, we got our shoes wet, I got sand in my panties, you got a sore throat and we got into a big fight and we did not see the grunions.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Ahh...we weren't in a good spot.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Hmm.  We didn't see them the year before either.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We just weren't in a good spot.  I'm telling you, this is a much better spot.  I have instincts for these things.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Look there, see?  What's that?  No, that's - that's just seaweed.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: God, this is great.  Think about this.  I know you are not interested, but just think about this.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Right now out there, there is this mass of silver fish and it's heading this way.  No one sent them an invitation, no one told them, no one even gave them a map.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Just all at once, they turned and they formed this line as long as the California coast.  And some instinctual little firecracker went off in their bodies and they all just turned as one and started swimming.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: They are swimming right now.  They are swimming as if that is the only thing that matters to them.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's single mindedness with no mind.  It is urgency that is just pure urge.

dialogue.text: Oh dear.  I'm bored with this conversation.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So am I.  I'm bored stiff. [GARBAGE]  Do you want some brandy?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.  Thank you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'll have a little, I think.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't know why you'd want any, you've already had three glasses.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No particular reason.  Anyhow, they are very small ones.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I just think it's silly to go on and on and on about such a thing.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You can hardly call three glasses of liquor a whole evening long, going on and on and on.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's become a habit with you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh.  Don't be so grand.  Just because you don't happen to want one at the moment.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Don't be stupid.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Really, Amanda.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Nothing.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: you going out somewhere, dear?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.  I am just making myself fascinating for you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That reply has broken my heart.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh.  It's a woman's duty to allure the man.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well as a matter of fact, yes, that's perfectly true.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No it isn't.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes it is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You shut up.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh really.  It's a pity you didn't have any brandy, it would have made you a little less disagreeable.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's funny it hasn't worked such wonders for you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Snap, snap, snap.  You know you are like a little adder.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Adders don't snap, they sting.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Nonsense.  They have a bag of venom behind their fangs and they snap. They snap.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: They sting. I don't care.  Do you understand?  I don't care if they bark and they roll about like hoops.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Did you see much of Peter Burden after our divorce?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes I did, quite a lot.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And I suppose you let him kiss you a good deal more than, too. Yes.  I suppose you guys had a riotous time, huh?  All out, no restraint at all.  Well, you never really had much anyhow.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Mind your own business.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're quite insufferable, I expect it's because you are drunk.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I think I am not in the least bit drunk.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You've always had a weak head.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I think I mentioned once before that I've had three minute liquor glasses the whole evening long.  A child of two cannot get drunk on that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: On the contrary, a child of two can get violently drunk on only one glass of brandy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That's very interesting Amanda. How about a child of four?  Or a child of six?  Or a child of nine? We can get a good little conversation going on about this, you know, intemperate tots.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh shut up.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Shut up.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Not very funny, darling.  Why don't you have some more brandy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER] That's a very good idea.  I think I will.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Look, you better turn that off. I don't want to wake up the people upstairs.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Why?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: There are no people upstairs; it's a photographer's studio.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well then you'll wake up the people downstairs.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: They are away in Tunis.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: This is no time of year for Tunis.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Turn it on again, please.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I will do no such thing.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Fine if you insist on being boorish and idiotic.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Will you turn that off, it's driving me mad.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You are far too temperamental, try to control yourself.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Turn it off.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I won't.  Let go, let go of me. Listen, listen?  I'm sick and tired of listening to you, you sadistic bully.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Amanda, listen, listen.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh.  That's very amusing indeed.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh shut up.  Let go.  I hate you, I hate you.  Do you hear?  You are a conceited and overbearing and utterly impossible.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You are a vile, ill-tempered, loose living, wicked little beast and I never want to see you again as long as I live.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: This is the end.  Do you hear me?  Finally and forever.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You're not going like this.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh.  Yes I am.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You're not.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes I am.   Stop it. Stop it.  Let go of me. Oh.  You're a cruel fiend.  I loathe and I hate you. Marry you again?  Never, never, never. I hope you die in torment, you brute beast cad.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Shut up. Shut up. God, I wouldn't marry you again if you came crawling back to me on a bended knee.  You are a vile, ill-tempered, mean little wench and I never want to see you again as long as I live.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Hey, Joy come in here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What's happening?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I have to go back.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I just got a letter I have to go back.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: When?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: First thing tomorrow morning.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Are you kidding me?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't understand, I don't underst--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How can they do that?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: They can do it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: They said you're home for at least four years.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I guess they can do it,

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: The National Guard is I guess really spread thin and then everyone has to go.  We all have to go back, my whole companies going back.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's not fair.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I can't believe it. I just got back.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So yeah, we leave tomorrow...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: ...we're all shipping out.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I just got I feel like I'm in shock actually.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't even know what to tell you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What about the birthday party?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I guess you're just going to have to have it without me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Hey listen, it's going to be okay though, all right?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You're going to be fine.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Me?  I'm not worried about me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm going to be fine too, okay?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How do you know?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know I have a good... I have a really good group of guys with me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We're going to be okay.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're going with the same ones?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Do promise me you're going to take a lot of pictures.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Always, I always do.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's not the same though.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I just wish there was something I could do.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: We could hide away.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Run away?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Mm hmm.  We'll build a bunker and never come out.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I really don't want to go, I don't want to go...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER] Mmm.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm scared.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Don't say that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'll send you a letter every single day.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I love you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I love you too.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Check this out.  You know how I've told you I've been really into like softball recently?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, this is totally random, I got this full ride scholarship to go to U.S.C next year to play softball.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER]. For softball? That's unbelievable. Is it slow pitch?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: For softball.  They're going to pay me to go to school. Isn't that awesome?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.  Well, I don't--well yeah I can pitch, I'm not like the pitcher though. I'm like the pinch hitter guy I mostly just hit.  But I guess I'm going to have to... Yeah, and then I play shortstop too but... It's so ex- The good news is I get to stay here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Uh huh.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Pinch hitting softball.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That is incredible.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's amazing. They pay for everything?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know. For softball, yeah.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Your housing, books, everything? That is incredible.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah, everything. Every like- free ride and I get to, you know, like be on like a Trojans sports team too. And it's like cool. Isn't it awesome?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That is incredible. Do you get like a per diem?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know. I should ask. Yeah, I will.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You should...You should look into that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That is amazing, congratulations. Good for you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Thank you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: But I don't know I want to live in the housing that they give me though 'cause I think I want to you know like get like a nicer place.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah, that you probably. You should see one of these Victorian houses around by.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Where should I move?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That's a really good idea. Or I could go to like Santa Monica. Go beach. Venice beach, yeah a little dirty though. I don't want to go to Venice beach. But - Malibu. All right.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh. Venice beach.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, you don't like that. You're west-sider?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Okay. That would be way too much of a commute you can't do that. Especially- I know especially from--I don't know, what I was going to say, I don't know.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Professional softball player Malibu. [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: From where? Huh? Well I'm from San Francisco.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't know. Commuting from what Malibu that would be ridiculous.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh yeah, that would be.  Well, depends on what type of car you had, though too. I guess it would be worth it. helicopter. Yeah, helicopter.  There is a helipad there, right? Yeah, exactly.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh yeah. He'd drop you right off at practice?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Do you--are you one of those like four a clock in the morning practices?  Is it--that's more like swimming and- --ballet and things like that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah. I think it's in the afternoon 'cause I mean can't be too early 'cause then you can't see the ball.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: They have those neon--softballs.  They're like day-glow you can see them anywhere.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah, but no. Well, they have a night games but you know there's more like night games they're not like morning games, you know. I guess it's kind of same thing.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm surprised you don't know that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh. That is incredible. Is it--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: do they have a--is it a co-ed softball team?  I mean... Really? You know, I didn't even know that they have that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No it's all boys. All boys' softball team.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: They do it's--believe me it's huge.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Who do you play? Like do--are you like... nationally ranked?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I just got into it. I just kind of fell into it. Literally I was walking around and...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That is unbelievable.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's pretty wild.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I would put that right up there with--ping-pong.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah, well I doubt [GARBAGE] ping pong [GARBAGE]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I mean not to denigrate what you are doing.  I think that's great.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh you mean it's not really sport that what you're saying?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, no.  I love softball. I played softball all the time.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's totally a sport. What are you talking about?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What, just 'cause I don't play regular baseball doesn't mean I'm like any less of like a sports guy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I am not saying you should be. I'm not no. I think it's great I think you should be incredibly proud yourself especially because you're going to U.S.C for free for doing it. For free.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: For free that's really what it's about. I mean who cares I mean if I have to play softball all the time?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: But they got to like drive around in a bus--that would suck.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh really? With the whole team?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah we have like away games and stuff.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What are your teammates like? I'm sure you don't know yet? What kind of people play softball?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: They're nice.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Like, you know like police officers, like--kind of heavyset guys. Mustaches, yeah. It's that kind of-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh really?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Cool. You don't seem like you'd fit in there.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That kind of...They're okay.  No I'm like- I'm kind of like the odd man out I'm like...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, cool.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: But you know I'm like [GARBAGE].

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're like the rookie? The new kid.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Just watch in five years you'll be like on the force. You carry around donuts in your back pocket... [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm going to have a mustache...On the force...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Pull over..

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What's he going to say?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Maybe we should tell him before he sees it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: He saw it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How could he see it?  I was the first one up; he was still in bed.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: He was out here when it broke.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: When?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Four o clock this morning.  I heard a crack and I woke up and looked out.  He was standing right over there when it cracked.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What was he doing out here at four o clock in the morning?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He's dreaming of him again, walking around.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I guess he is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's getting to be just like after he died.  What's the meaning of that?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know the meaning of it.  But I know one thing, Mom, you've made a terrible mistake with father.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Being dishonest with him, you know.  This kind of thing always pays off and it's paying off.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What do you mean dishonest?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know Larry is not coming back and I know it.  Why do we allow him to go on thinking that we believe with him?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What do you want to do?  Argue with him?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't want to argue but it's time he realized that nobody believes Larry is alive.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know?  Why shouldn't he walk the nights thinking of him, dreaming of him?   Do we contradict him?  Do we say, we don't have any hope anymore?  That we haven't had any hope for years now?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You can't say that to him.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We've got to say it to him.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Where's the proof?  Do you have any proof?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: For God's sake, three years?  Nobody comes back after three years; that's insane.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: To you it is, to me it is, but to your father, you can talk yourself until you are blue in the face.  But there is no grave and there is no body, so where are you?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Sit down, Mom.  I want to talk to you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's that the trouble is those God damn newspapers.  Every month some new boy comes back and so the next one is going to be Larry, they just--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All right, all right, all right.  You know why I asked Annie here, right?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Why?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well I got an idea, but what's your story?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm going to ask her to marry me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well that's only your business, Chris.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know it's not just my business.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well what do you want me to do?  You're old enough to know your own mind.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So all right then, I'll just go ahead with it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well you want to make sure that your father is not going to --

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Then it's not just my business.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm just saying.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know sometimes you infuriate me.  you know that?  Isn't it your business if I tell father and he throws a fit about it?  God, you have such a talent for ignoring things.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh.  I ignore what I got to ignore.  That girl is Larry's girl.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: She's not Larry's girl.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: From your father's point of view, he is not dead and- Chris he still thinks he's still alive.  The girl is Larry's girl.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Now you can go on from there if you know where to go, but I'm telling you, I don't know where to go.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know why it is, but every time I reach out for something I have to pull back because I am afraid other people will suffer. My whole bloody life, time after time.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're a considerate fellow, there's nothing wrong in that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: To hell with that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I just don't see why.  Have you asked Annie yet?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I wanted to get this settled first.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well how do you know she's going to marry you?  Maybe she feels the same way your father does.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well if she does, then that's it.  That's the end of it.  From her letters, though, I think she's pretty much forgotten him.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And then we'll thrash it out with father.  Okay Mom?  Don't avoid me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: The trouble is you don't see enough women.  You never did.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So what.  I'm not fast with women.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Why does it have to be Annie?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Because it is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh that's a great reason.  It's no reason at all.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You haven't seen her since you went away to war, it's been five years.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I can't help it, I know her best.  I was brought up next door to her, you know?  These years when I think of someone for my wife, I think of Annie.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Mom, what do you want?  A diagram?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't want a diagram.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He thinks he's coming back Chris.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You marry that girl, you are pronouncing him dead...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: ...and then what's that going to do to your father?  Do you know?  I don't.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All right, then, Mom. [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Just give it some more thought.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I've given it three years of thought.  And I'd hope that if I waited, father would forget about Larry and then we could just have a regular wedding and everyone would be happy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: But if I can't do that here, I may have to go somewhere else.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What the hell is this?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'll get out.  I'll get married and I'll move somewhere else, maybe New York.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Are you crazy?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I've been a good son for too long, a good sucker.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You have a business here.  What the hell is this?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: The business?  The business doesn't inspire me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh.  Must you be inspired?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes.  I like it for an hour a day.  I don't care if I have to grub for money all day long, when I come home I want it happy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I want some kids, I want a family, I want somebody that I can give myself to and Annie is in the center of that.  Now it's just where to find it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You mean to tell me that you would leave the business over this?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: On this, I would.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well you don't want to think like that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Then help me stay here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: All right.  But you don't want to think like that because what the hell are we working for, Chris?  It's all for you.  This whole shooting match is for you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know that.  Then just help me stay here.

dialogue.speaker: F

You know, and maybe once you get to know some more people, like talking to them and everything, they'll get to know you too and they'll realize they should've hired you three years ago. Like it's like suddenly it starts to feel like it's just you that they say no to and it's not that they're not taking applications and it's not that they're not hiring people, it's just you particularly they have some particular reason for just hating you.  You know?
